questions.answer: We call God Our Father and not my Father, because we are all His children, and hence we should look on and love one another as brothers and pray for one another.

questions.question: God being in every place, why do we say: Who art in heaven?
questions.answer: God is in every place; but we say: Our Father who art in heaven, to raise our hearts to heaven, where God manifests His glory to His children. #### The First Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the First Petition when we say: Hallowed be Thy Name?
questions.answer: In the First Petition: Hallowed be Thy Name, we ask that God may be known, loved, honoured and served by the whole world and by ourselves in particular.

questions.question: What do we intend when we ask that God may be known, loved, honoured and served by the whole world?
questions.answer: We intend to beg that infidels may come to the knowledge of the Lord God, that heretics may recognise their errors, that schismatics may return to the unity of the Church, that sinners may repent, and that the just may persevere in well-doing.

questions.question: Why do we first of all ask that the Name of God may be sanctified?
questions.answer: We first of all ask that the Name of God may be sanctified, because the glory of God should be nearer our hearts than all other goods and interests.

questions.question: How can we promote the glory of God?
questions.answer: We can promote the glory of God by prayer, by good example, and by directing to Him all our thoughts, affections and actions. #### The Second Petition

questions.question: What do we mean by the Kingdom of God?
questions.answer: By the Kingdom of God we mean a threefold spiritual Kingdom; that is, the reign of God in us, or the reign of grace; the reign of God on earth, or the Holy Catholic Church; and the reign of God in heaven, or Paradise.

questions.question: In the words: Thy Kingdom come, what do we ask with regard to grace?
questions.answer: With regard to grace we beg that God may reign in us by His sanctifying grace, by which He deigns to dwell within us as a king in his palace; and that He may keep us ever united to Himself by the virtues of faith, hope and charity, through which He reigns over our intellect, our heart and our will.

questions.question: In the words: Thy Kingdom come, what do we ask regarding the Church?
questions.answer: Regarding the Church we ask that she may be spread and propagated ever more and more throughout the world for the salvation of mankind.

questions.question: In the words: Thy Kingdom come, what do we ask regarding Heaven?
questions.answer: Regarding Heaven we beg to be one day admitted into that Paradise for which we were created and where we shall be perfectly happy. #### The Third Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the Third Petition: Thy will be done on earth as it is in Heaven?
questions.answer: In the Third Petition: Thy will be done on earth as it is in Heaven, we beg the grace to do the will of God in all things by obeying His Commandments as promptly as the Angels and Saints obey Him in Heaven; and we also beg the grace to correspond to divine inspirations and to live resigned to the will of God should He send us tribulations.

questions.question: Is it necessary to do the will of God?
questions.answer: It is as necessary to do the will of God as it is to work out our salvation, because Jesus Christ has said that they alone who have done the will of His Father shall enter into the Kingdom of Heaven.

questions.question: In what way can we know the will of God?
questions.answer: We can know the will of God especially by means of the Church and of the spiritual superiors appointed by God to guide us along the way of salvation; we may also learn His most holy will from the divine inspirations that come to us and from the very surroundings in which the Lord has placed us.

questions.question: Should we always recognise the will of God in adversity as well as in prosperity?
questions.answer: Both in prosperity and adversity we should always recognise the will of God, who directs or permits all things for our good. #### The Fourth Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the Fourth Petition: Give us this day our daily bread?
questions.answer: In the Fourth Petition we beg of God all that is daily necessary for soul and body.

questions.question: What do we ask of God for our soul?
questions.answer: For our soul we ask of God the sustenance of our spiritual life, that is, we pray the Lord to give us His grace of which we stand in continual need.

questions.question: How is the life of the soul nourished?
questions.answer: The life of the soul is nourished principally by the food of the word of God and by the Most Holy Sacrament of the Altar.

questions.question: What do we ask of God for our body?
questions.answer: For the body we ask all that is necessary for the sustainment of our temporal life.

questions.question: Why do we say: Give us this day our daily bread, rather than: Give us bread this day?
questions.answer: We say: Give us this day our daily bread, rather than: Give us bread this day, to exclude all desire of what is another's; and hence we beg the Lord to help us in acquiring just and lawful gains, so that we may procure our maintenance by our own toil And without theft or fraud.

questions.question: Why do we say: Give us bread, and not: Give me bread?
questions.answer: We say: Give us, rather than, Give me, to remind us that as everything comes from God, so if He gives us His gifts in abundance, He does it in order that we may share what we do not need with the poor.

questions.question: Why do we add: Daily?
questions.answer: We add, Daily, because we should desire that which is necessary to life, and not an abundance of food and other goods of the earth.

questions.question: What more does Daily signify in the Fourth Petition?
questions.answer: The word Daily signifies that we should not be too solicitous regarding the future, but that we should simply ask what we need at present. #### The Fifth Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the Fifth Petition; And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive them that trespass against us?
questions.answer: In the Fifth Petition: And forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us, we ask God to pardon us our sins as we pardon those who offend us.

questions.question: Why are our sins called debts?
questions.answer: Our sins are called debts, because we must satisfy God's justice for them either in this life or in the next.

questions.question: Can those who do not forgive their neighbour hope that God will pardon them?
questions.answer: Those who do not forgive their neighbour have no reason to hope that God will pardon them; especially since they condemn themselves when they ask God to forgive them as they forgive their neighbour. #### The Sixth Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the Sixth Petition: And lead us not into temptation?
questions.answer: In the Sixth Petition: And lead us not into temptation, we ask God to deliver us from temptation either by not allowing us to be tempted, or by giving us grace not to be conquered.

questions.question: What are temptations?
questions.answer: Temptations are an incitement to sin that comes from the devil, or from the wicked, or from our own evil passions.

questions.question: Is it a sin to have temptations?
questions.answer: No, it is no sin to have temptations; but it is a sin to consent to them, or voluntarily to expose oneself to the danger of consenting to them.

questions.question: Why does God allow us to be tempted?
questions.answer: God allows us to be tempted so as to test our fidelity, increase our virtue, and augment our merits.

questions.question: What should we do to avoid temptations?
questions.answer: To avoid temptation we should fly dangerous occasions, guard our senses, receive the sacraments frequently, and have recourse to the practice of prayer. #### The Seventh Petition

questions.question: What do we ask in the Seventh Petition: But deliver us from evil?
questions.answer: In the Seventh Petition: But deliver us from evil, we ask God to free us from evils, past, present, and future, and particularly from the greatest of all evils which is sin, and from eternal d***ation, which is its penalty.

questions.question: Why do we say: Deliver us from evil and not: From evils?
questions.answer: We say: Deliver us from evil, and not, from evils, because we should not desire to be exempt from all the evils of this life, but only from those which are not good for our souls; and hence we beg liberation from evil in general, that is, from whatever God sees would be bad for us.

questions.question: Is it not lawful to beg liberation from some evil in particular, for example, from sickness?
questions.answer: Yes, it is lawful to beg liberation from some evil in particular but always in bowing to the will of God, who may even ordain that particular affliction for the good of our soul.

questions.question: How do the tribulations, which God sends us, help us?
questions.answer: Tribulations help us to do penance for our sins, to practise virtue, and above all to imitate Jesus Christ, our Head, to whom it is fitting we should conform ourselves in our sufferings, if we wish to have a share in His glory.

questions.question: What is the meaning of Amen at the end of the Our Father?
questions.answer: Amen means: So be it; So I do desire; Thus do I pray the Lord; Thus do I hope.

questions.question: To obtain the graces asked in the Our Father is it enough to recite it any way at all?
questions.answer: To obtain the graces asked in the Our Father we must recite it without haste and with attention; and we must put our heart into it.

questions.question: When should we say the Our Father?
questions.answer: We should say the Our Father every day, because every day we have need of God's help.

questions.question: What prayer do we usually say after the Our Father?
questions.answer: After the Our Father we say the Angelic Salutation, that is, the Hail Mary, through which we have recourse to the Blessed Virgin.

questions.question: Why is the Hail Mary called the Angelic Salutation?
questions.answer: The Hail Mary is called the Angelic Salutation, because it begins with the salutation addressed by the Archangel Gabriel to the Virgin Mary.

questions.question: Whose are the words of the Hail Mary?
questions.answer: The words of the Hail Mary are partly the Archangel Gabriel's, partly Saint Elizabeth's, and partly the Church's.

questions.question: Which are the words of the Archangel Gabriel?
questions.answer: The words of the Archangel Gabriel are these: Hail, full of grace, The Lord is with thee; blessed art thou among women.

questions.question: When was it that the angel said these words to Mary?
questions.answer: The angel said these words to Mary when he went to announce to her, on the part of God, the mystery of the Incarnation that was to be wrought in her.

questions.question: What is our object in saluting the Blessed Virgin with the very words of the Archangel?
questions.answer: In saluting the Blessed Virgin with the words of the Archangel we congratulate her by recalling to mind the singular privileges and gifts which God has granted her in preference to all other creatures.

questions.question: Which are the words of Saint Elizabeth?
questions.answer: The words of Saint Elizabeth are these: Blessed art thou among women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb.

questions.question: When was it that Saint Elizabeth said these words?
questions.answer: Saint Elizabeth, inspired by God, said these words when, three months before she gave birth to Saint John the Baptist, she was visited by the Blessed Virgin, who then bore her Divine Son in her womb.

questions.question: What do we intend by saying these words?
questions.answer: In saying the words of Saint Elizabeth we congratulate the Blessed Virgin on her high dignity as Mother of God, and we bless God and thank Him for having given us Jesus Christ through Mary.

questions.question: Whose are the other words of the Hail Mary?
questions.answer: All the other words of the Hail Mary have been added by the Church.

questions.question: What do we ask in the last part of the Hail Mary?
questions.answer: In the last part of the Hail Mary we beg the protection of the Blessed Virgin during this life and especially at the hour of death, when we shall have greater need of it.

questions.question: Why do we say the Hail Mary, rather than any other prayer, after the Our Father?
questions.answer: Because the Blessed Virgin is our most powerful advocate with Jesus Christ, and hence, after having said the prayer taught us by Jesus Christ, we pray the Blessed Virgin to obtain for us the graces we have asked therein.

questions.question: Why is the Blessed Virgin so powerful?
questions.answer: The Blessed Virgin is so powerful, because, being the Mother of God, she cannot but be heard by Him.

questions.question: What do the Saints teach us on devotion to Mary?
questions.answer: Regarding devotion to Mary the Saints teach us that those who are truly devout to her are loved and protected by her with a most tender Mother's love, and that with her help they are sure to find Jesus find and obtain Paradise.

questions.question: What form of devotion to Mary does the Church recommend in a very special manner?
questions.answer: The devotion to the Blessed Virgin which the Church specially recommends is the Holy Rosary.

questions.question: What is treated of in the fourth part of the Christian Doctrine?
questions.answer: In the fourth part of the Christian Doctrine the sacraments are treated of.

questions.question: What is meant by the word sacrament?
questions.answer: By the word sacrament is meant a sensible and efficacious sign of grace, instituted by Christ to sanctify our souls.

questions.question: Why do you call the sacraments sensible and efficacious signs of grace?
questions.answer: I call the sacraments sensible and efficacious signs of grace because all the sacraments signify by means of sensible things, the divine grace which they produce in our souls. **Show by an example how the sacraments are sensible and efficacious signs of grace.** In Baptism the pouring of water on the head of the person, and the words: 'I baptise thee,' that is, I wash thee, 'in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost,' are a sensible sign of that which Baptism accomplishes in the soul; just as water washes the body, so in like manner does the grace given in Baptism cleanse the soul from sin.

questions.question: How many sacraments are there, and what are they called?
questions.answer: There are seven sacraments: Baptism, Confirmation, Eucharist, Penance, Extreme Unction, Holy Orders and Matrimony.

questions.question: What is necessary to constitute a sacrament?
questions.answer: To constitute a sacrament it is necessary to have the matter, the form, and the minister, who must have the intention to do what the Church does.

questions.question: What is the matter of the sacraments?
questions.answer: The matter of the sacraments is the sensible thing made use of in effecting the sacrament; such as, for example, natural water in Baptism, oil and balsam in Confirmation.

questions.question: What is the form of the sacraments?
questions.answer: The form of the sacraments is the words which are pronounced in order to effect the sacrament.

questions.question: Who is the minister of the sacraments?
questions.answer: The minister of the sacraments is the person who administers or confers the sacrament.

subsections.title: The Principal Effect of the Sacraments: Grace

questions.question: What is grace?
questions.answer: Grace is an inward and supernatural gift given to us without any merit of our own, but through the merits of Jesus Christ in order to gain eternal life.

questions.question: How is grace distinguished?
questions.answer: Grace is divided into sanctifying grace, which is also called habitual grace, and actual grace.

questions.question: What is sanctifying grace?
questions.answer: Sanctifying grace is a supernatural gift inherent in our soul, and rendering us just, adopted children of God and heirs to Paradise.

questions.question: How many kinds of sanctifying grace are there?
questions.answer: Sanctifying grace is of two kinds: first grace and second grace.

questions.question: What is first grace?
questions.answer: First grace is that by means of which one passes from the state of mortal sin to the state of justice.

questions.question: And what is second grace?
questions.answer: Second grace is an increase of first grace.

questions.question: What is actual grace?
questions.answer: Actual grace is a supernatural gift which enlightens the mind, moves and strengthens the will in order to enable us to do good and avoid evil.

questions.question: Can we resist the grace of God?
questions.answer: Yes, we can resist the grace of God because it does not destroy our free will.

questions.question: By the aid of our own powers alone can we do anything available to life eternal?
questions.answer: Without the help of the grace of God, and by our own powers alone, we cannot do anything helpful to life everlasting.

questions.question: How is grace given us by God?
questions.answer: Grace is given us by God chiefly through the sacraments.

questions.question: Do the sacraments confer any other grace besides sanctifying grace?
questions.answer: Besides sanctifying grace the sacraments also confer sacramental grace.

questions.question: What is sacramental grace?
questions.answer: Sacramental grace consists in the right acquired in the reception of a sacrament, to have at the proper time the actual graces necessary to fulfil the obligations arising from the sacrament received. Thus when we were baptised we received the right to have the grace to live a Christian life.

questions.question: Do the sacraments always confer grace on those who receive them?
questions.answer: The sacraments always confer grace provided they are received with the necessary dispositions.

questions.question: Who gave to the sacraments the power of conferring grace?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ by His passion and death gave to the sacraments the power of conferring grace.

questions.question: What sacraments confer first sanctifying grace?
questions.answer: The sacraments which confer first sanctifying grace, and render us friends of God, are two: Baptism and Penance.

questions.question: How are these two sacraments called on that account?
questions.answer: These two sacraments, Baptism and Penance, are on that account called sacraments of the dead, because they are instituted chiefly to restore to the life of grace the soul dead by sin.

questions.question: Which are the sacraments that increase grace in those who already possess it?
questions.answer: The sacraments which increase grace in those who already possess it are the other five: Confirmation, Eucharist, Extreme Unction, Holy Orders and Matrimony, all of which confer second grace.

questions.question: On this account how are they called?
questions.answer: These five sacraments - Confirmation, Eucharist, Extreme Unction, Holy Orders and Matrimony - are on that account called sacraments of the living, because those who receive them must be free from mortal sin, that is, already alive through sanctifying grace.

questions.question: What sin does he commit who, conscious that he is not in a state of grace, receives one of the sacraments of the living?
questions.answer: He who conscious that he is not in a state of grace, receives one of the sacraments of the living, commits a serious sacrilege.

questions.question: What sacraments are most necessary for salvation?
questions.answer: The sacraments most necessary to salvation are two: Baptism and Penance. Baptism is necessary to all, and Penance is necessary to all who have sinned mortally after Baptism.

questions.question: What is the greatest of all the sacraments?
questions.answer: The greatest of all the sacraments is the Eucharist, because it contains not only grace, but also Jesus Christ the Author of Grace and of the Sacraments.

subsections.title: The Character Impressed by some of the Sacraments

questions.question: What sacraments can be received only once?
questions.answer: The sacraments that can be received only once are three: Baptism, Confirmation, and Holy Orders.

questions.question: Why can the three sacraments of Baptism, Confirmation and Holy Orders be received only once?
questions.answer: The three sacraments, Baptism, Confirmation and Holy Orders can be received only once, because each of them imprints a special character on the soul.

questions.question: What is the character that each of the three sacraments, Baptism, Confirmation and Holy Orders imprints on the soul?
questions.answer: The character that each of the three sacraments, Baptism, Confirmation, and Holy Orders imprints on the soul is a spiritual mark that is never effaced.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the character that these three sacraments impress on the soul?
questions.answer: The character that these three sacraments imprint on the soul, serves to mark us as members of Jesus Christ at Baptism, as His soldiers at Confirmation, and as His ministers at Holy Orders.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of Baptism?
questions.answer: Baptism is a sacrament by which we are born again to the grace of God, and become Christians.

questions.question: What are the effects of the sacrament of Baptism?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Baptism confers first sanctifying grace by which original sin is washed away, as well as all actual sin if any such exists; it remits all punishment due on account of such sins; it imprints the character of a Christian; it makes us children of God, members of the Church, and heirs to Paradise, and enables us to receive the other sacraments.

questions.question: What is the matter of Baptism?
questions.answer: The matter of Baptism is natural water which is poured on the head of the person to be baptised in such a quantity as to flow.

questions.question: What is the form of Baptism?
questions.answer: The form of Baptism is: 'I baptise thee in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost.' #### Minister of Baptism

questions.question: To whom does it belong to confer Baptism?
questions.answer: To confer Baptism belongs by right to bishops and parish priests, but in case of necessity any person, whether man or woman, even a heretic or an infidel, can administer it, provided he carries out the rite of Baptism, and has the intention of doing what the Church does.

questions.question: If it were necessary to baptise a person in danger of death, and if several people were present, who should administer the sacrament?
questions.answer: If it were necessary to baptise a person in danger of death, and if several people were present, a priest, if such were at hand, should administer the Sacrament, and, in his absence, one of the inferior clergy; and in the absence of such, a layman in preference to a woman, unless in the case in which the greater skill on the part of the woman, or the claims of propriety, should demand otherwise.

questions.question: What intention should the person baptising have?
questions.answer: The person baptising should have the intention of doing what Holy Church does in baptising. #### The Rite of Baptism and the Disposition of the Adult who Receives It

questions.question: How is Baptism given?
questions.answer: Baptism is given by pouring water on the head of the person to be baptised - and if it cannot be poured on the head, then on some other principal part of the body - saying at the same time: 'I baptise thee in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.'

questions.question: If one were to pour the water and another to pronounce the words would the person be baptised?
questions.answer: If one poured the water and another said the words the person would not be baptised; because it is necessary that the person who pours the water should pronounce the words.

questions.question: When in doubt whether the person is dead, is it right to omit baptising him?
questions.answer: When in doubt whether the person is dead, he should be baptised conditionally, saying: 'If thou art alive I baptise thee in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.'

questions.question: When should infants be brought to the Church to be baptised?
questions.answer: Infants should be brought to the Church to be baptised as soon as possible.

questions.question: Why such anxiety to have infants receive Baptism?
questions.answer: There should be the greatest anxiety to have infants baptised because, on account of their tender age, they are exposed to many dangers of death, and cannot be saved without Baptism.

questions.question: Do parents sin, then, who, through negligence, allow their children to die without Baptism, or who defer it?
questions.answer: Yes, fathers and mothers who, through negligence, allow their children to die without Baptism sin grievously, because they deprive their children of eternal life; and they also sin grievously by putting off Baptism for a long time, because they expose them to danger of dying without having received it.

questions.question: When the person who is being baptised is an adult, what dispositions should he have?
questions.answer: An adult who is being baptised, besides faith, should have at least imperfect contrition for the mortal sins he may have committed.

questions.question: If an adult in mortal sin was baptised without such sorrow, what would he receive?
questions.answer: If an adult was baptised in mortal sin without such sorrow he would receive the character of Baptism, but not the remission of his sins nor sanctifying grace. And these two effects would be suspended, until the obstacle is removed by perfect contrition or by the sacrament of Penance. #### Necessity of Baptism and Obligations of the Baptised

questions.question: Is Baptism necessary to salvation?
questions.answer: Baptism is absolutely necessary to salvation, for our Lord has expressly said: 'Unless a man be born again of water and the Holy Ghost, he cannot enter into the Kingdom of God.'

questions.question: Can the absence of Baptism be supplied in any other way?
questions.answer: The absence of Baptism can be supplied by martyrdom, which is called Baptism of Blood, or by an act of perfect love of God, or of contrition, along with the desire, at least implicit, of Baptism, and this is called Baptism of Desire.

questions.question: To what is the person baptised bound?
questions.answer: The person baptised is bound to always profess the faith and observe the Law of Jesus Christ and of His Church.

questions.question: In receiving holy Baptism what do we renounce?
questions.answer: In receiving holy Baptism we renounce, for ever, the devil, his works and pomps.

questions.question: What is meant by the works and pomps of the devil?
questions.answer: By the works and pomps of the devil we mean sin and the maxims of the world that are contrary to the maxims of the Gospel. #### Names and Sponsors

questions.question: Why is the name of a saint given to him who is being baptised?
questions.answer: To him who is being baptised is given the name of a saint in order to put him under the protection of a heavenly patron and to animate him to imitate that saint's example.

questions.question: Who are the godfathers and godmothers in Baptism?
questions.answer: The godfathers and godmothers in Baptism are those persons who, in accordance with the decree of the Church, hold the infants at the font, answer for them, and become guarantees in the sight of God for their Christian education, especially in the absence of the parents.

questions.question: Are we obliged to keep the promises and renunciations made for us by our sponsors?
questions.answer: We are certainly obliged to observe the promises and renunciations made for us by our sponsors, because it is only on this condition that God has received us into His grace.

questions.question: What sort of persons should be chosen as godfathers and godmothers?
questions.answer: There should be chosen as godfathers and godmothers Catholics of good life, and obedient to the laws of the Church.

questions.question: What are the obligations of godfathers and godmothers?
questions.answer: Godfathers and godmothers are bound to see that their spiritual children are instructed in the truths of faith, and live as good Christians and they should edify them by their good example.

questions.question: What tie do sponsors contract in Baptism?
questions.answer: Sponsors contract a spiritual relationship with the baptised and with the parents of the baptised, which causes an impediment to marriage with these persons.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: Confirmation is a sacrament which gives us the Holy Ghost, imprints on our souls the mark of a soldier of Jesus Christ, and makes us perfect Christians.

questions.question: How does the sacrament of Confirmation make us perfect Christians?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Confirmation makes us perfect Christians by confirming us in the faith and perfecting the other virtues and gifts received in Baptism; hence it is called Confirmation.

questions.question: What gifts of the Holy Ghost are received in Confirmation?
questions.answer: The gifts of the Holy Ghost received in Confirmation are these seven: Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Fortitude, Knowledge, Piety, and the Fear of the Lord.

questions.question: What is the matter of this sacrament?
questions.answer: The matter of this sacrament, besides the imposition of hands by the bishop, is the anointing of the forehead of the baptised with sacred chrism; and for this reason it is also called the sacrament of Chrism, that is Anointing.

questions.question: What is sacred Chrism?
questions.answer: Sacred Chrism is oil of olive mingled with balsam, and consecrated by the bishop on Holy Thursday.

questions.question: What do the oil and balsam in this sacrament signify?
questions.answer: In this sacrament the oil, which is unctuous and strengthening, signifies the abounding grace which is diffused over the soul of the Christian to confirm him in his faith; and the balsam, which is fragrant and prevents corruption, signifies that the Christian, strengthened by this grace, is enabled to give forth a good odour of Christian virtue and preserve himself from the corruption of vice.

questions.question: What is the form of the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: The form of the sacrament of Confirmation is this: 'I sign thee with the Sign of the Cross, and I confirm thee with the chrism of salvation, in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost. Amen.'

questions.question: Who is the minister of the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: The ordinary minister of the sacrament of Confirmation is the bishop alone.

questions.question: How does the bishop administer Confirmation?
questions.answer: In administering the sacrament of Confirmation the bishop first stretches his hands over those to be confirmed, and invokes the Holy Ghost upon them; next, he anoints the forehead of each one with sacred chrism in the form of a cross, saying the words of the form; then he gives each one confirmed a light stroke on the cheek with his right hand, saying: Peace be with you; finally, he solemnly blesses all those he has confirmed.

questions.question: Why is the anointing made on the forehead?
questions.answer: The anointing is made on the forehead, where signs of fear and shame appear, in order that he who is confirmed may understand that he should not blush at the name and profession of a Christian, nor fear the enemies of his faith.

questions.question: Why is a light stroke given to the person confirmed?
questions.answer: A light stroke is given to the person confirmed to show him that he should be ready to bear all insults and endure all sufferings for the faith of Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Should all endeavour to receive the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: Yes, all should endeavour to receive the sacrament of Confirmation and to have those under them receive it.

questions.question: At what age is it advisable to receive the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: The age at which it is advisable to receive the sacrament of Confirmation is about the seventh year, because it is then that temptations usually begin, and the grace of the sacrament can be sufficiently discerned and a recollection be had of having received it.

questions.question: What dispositions are required to receive worthily the sacrament of Confirmation?
questions.answer: To receive worthily the sacrament of Confirmation it is necessary to be in the grace of God; know the principal mysteries of our holy faith; and approach it with reverence and devotion.

questions.question: Would he who received Confirmation a second time be guilty of sin?
questions.answer: He would commit a sacrilege; because Confirmation is one of the sacraments that imprint a character on the soul and hence may be received only once.

questions.question: What should a Christian do to preserve the grace of Confirmation?
questions.answer: To preserve the grace of Confirmation a Christian should pray often, do good works, and live according to the laws of Jesus Christ, in spite of human respect.

questions.question: Why are there also godfathers and godmothers in Confirmation?
questions.answer: In order that, by word and example, they may show the confirmed the way to eternal life and help him in the spiritual combat.

questions.question: What qualifications are required in sponsors?
questions.answer: They should be of proper age, Catholics, confirmed, instructed in the necessary truths of religion, and persons of good life.

questions.question: Does a sponsor in Confirmation contract any relationship with the confirmed and the parents of the confirmed?
questions.answer: The sponsor in Confirmation contracts the same spiritual relationship as is contracted in Baptism.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of the Eucharist?
questions.answer: The Eucharist is a sacrament in which, by the marvellous conversion of the whole substance of bread into the Body of Jesus Christ, and that of wine into His precious Blood, is contained truly, really, and substantially, the Body, the Blood, the Soul and Divinity of the same Lord Jesus Christ, under the appearance of bread and wine as our spiritual food.

questions.question: In the Eucharist is there the same Jesus Christ who is in heaven, and who was born on earth of the Blessed Virgin?
questions.answer: Yes, in the Eucharist there is truly the same Jesus Christ who is in heaven, and who was born on earth of the Blessed Virgin.

questions.question: Why do you believe that in the Eucharist Jesus Christ is really present?
questions.answer: I believe that in the Eucharist Jesus Christ is truly present, because He Himself has said it, and holy Church teaches it.

questions.question: What is the matter of the sacrament of the Eucharist?
questions.answer: The matter of the sacrament of the Eucharist is that which was used by Jesus Christ Himself, that is, wheaten bread and wine of the vine.

questions.question: What is the form of the sacrament of the Eucharist?
questions.answer: The form of the sacrament of the Eucharist consists of the words used by Jesus Christ Himself: 'This is My Body: This is My Blood.'

questions.question: What is the host before consecration?
questions.answer: The host before consecration is bread.

questions.question: After consecration what is the host?
questions.answer: After consecration the host is the true Body of our Lord Jesus Christ under the species of bread.

questions.question: What is in the chalice before consecration?
questions.answer: In the chalice before consecration there is wine with a few drops of water.

questions.question: After consecration what is in the chalice?
questions.answer: After consecration there is in the chalice the true Blood of our Lord Jesus Christ, under the species of wine.

questions.question: When does the change of the bread into the Body and of the wine into the Blood of Jesus Christ take place?
questions.answer: The change of the bread into the Body and of the wine into the Blood of Jesus Christ is made in the very moment in which the priest pronounces the words of consecration during holy Mass.

questions.question: What is the consecration?
questions.answer: The consecration is the renewal, by means of the priest, of the miracle wrought by Jesus Christ at the Last Supper, of changing bread and wine into His adorable Body and Blood by saying: 'This is My Body: This is My Blood.'

questions.question: What does the Church call the miraculous change of bread and of wine into the Body and Blood of Jesus Christ?
questions.answer: The Church calls the miraculous change which is daily wrought upon our altars transubstantiation.

questions.question: Who gave this great power to the words of consecration?
questions.answer: Our Lord Jesus Christ Himself, who is Almighty God, gave this great power to the words of consecration.

questions.question: Is there nothing left of the bread and of the wine after consecration?
questions.answer: After consecration the species of the bread and of the wine alone are left.

questions.question: What are the species of the bread and of the wine?
questions.answer: The species of the bread and of the wine are the quantity and sensible qualities of the bread and of the wine, such as the form, the colour, and the taste.

questions.question: How can the species of the bread and of the wine remain without their substance?
questions.answer: The species of the bread and of the wine remain without their substance in a wonderful way by the power of God Almighty.

questions.question: Under the species of the bread is there only the Body of Jesus Christ and under the species of the wine only His Blood?
questions.answer: Both under the species of the bread and under the species of the wine the living Jesus Christ is all present, with His Body, His Blood, His Soul and His Divinity.

questions.question: Can you tell me why Jesus Christ is whole and entire both in the host and in the chalice?
questions.answer: Both in the host and in the chalice Jesus Christ is whole and entire, because He is living and immortal in the Eucharist as He is in heaven; hence where His Body is, there also are His Blood, His Soul, and His Divinity; and where His Blood is, there also are His Body, His Soul and His Divinity, all these being inseparable in Jesus Christ.

questions.question: When Jesus Christ is in the host does He cease to be in heaven?
questions.answer: When Jesus Christ is in the host He does not cease to be in heaven, but is at one and the same time in heaven and in the Blessed Sacrament.

questions.question: Is Jesus Christ present in all the consecrated hosts in the world?
questions.answer: Yes, Jesus Christ is present in all consecrated hosts in the world.

questions.question: How can Jesus Christ be present in all the consecrated hosts in the world?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ is present in all the consecrated hosts in the world by the Omnipotence of God, to whom nothing is impossible.

questions.question: When the host is broken is the Body of Jesus Christ broken also?
questions.answer: When the host is broken, the Body of Jesus Christ is not broken, but only the species of the bread are broken.

questions.question: In which part of the host is the Body of Jesus Christ?
questions.answer: The Body of Jesus Christ is entire in all the parts into which the host is broken.

questions.question: Is Jesus Christ just as much in a particle of a host as in a whole host?
questions.answer: Yes, the same Jesus Christ is just as much in a particle of a host as in a whole host.

questions.question: Why is the Most Blessed Eucharist preserved in our churches?
questions.answer: The Most Blessed Eucharist is preserved in our churches that It may be adored by the faithful, and brought to the sick when necessary.

questions.question: Ought the Eucharist to be adored?
questions.answer: The Eucharist ought to be adored by all, because it contains really, truly, and substantially, our Lord Jesus Christ Himself. #### The Institution and Effects of the Sacrament of the Eucharist

questions.question: When did Jesus Christ institute the sacrament of the Eucharist?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ instituted the sacrament of the Eucharist at the last supper, which He took with His disciples, the evening before His passion.

questions.question: Why did Jesus Christ institute the Most Holy Eucharist?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ instituted the Most Holy Eucharist for three principal reasons: (1) To be the Sacrifice of the New Law; (2) To be the food of our souls; (3) To be a perpetual memorial of His passion and death and a precious pledge both of His love for us and of eternal life.

questions.question: Why did Jesus Christ institute this sacrament under the appearances of bread and wine?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ instituted this sacrament under the appearances of bread and wine, because, the Eucharist being intended to be our spiritual nourishment, it was therefore fitting that it should be given to us under the form of food and drink.

questions.question: What are the effects which the Most Holy Eucharist produces in us?
questions.answer: The principal effects which the Most Holy Eucharist produces in those who worthily receive it are these: (1) It preserves and increases the life of the soul, which is grace, just as natural food sustains and increases the life of the body; (2) It remits venial sins and preserves us from mortal sin; (3) It produces spiritual consolation.

questions.question: Does not the Most Holy Eucharist produce other effects in us?
questions.answer: Yes; the Most Holy Eucharist produces three other effects in us: (1) It weakens our passions, and in particular it allays in us the fires of concupiscence; (2) It increases in us the fervour of charity towards God and our neighbour, and aids us to act in conformity with the will of Jesus Christ; (3) It gives us a pledge of future glory and of the resurrection of our body. #### The Dispositions Necessary to Receive Holy Communion Worthily

questions.question: Does the sacrament of the Eucharist always produce its marvellous effects in us?
questions.answer: The sacrament of the Eucharist produces its marvellous effects in us when it is received with the requisite dispositions.

questions.question: What conditions are necessary to make a good Communion?
questions.answer: To make a good communion three conditions are necessary: (1) To be in the grace of God; (2) To be fasting from midnight until the moment of Holy Communion; (3) To know what we are about to receive, and to approach Holy Communion devoutly. [The fast from midnight was the old Eucharistic discipline. In view of evening Masses which became more frequent at his time, Pope Pius XII gave permission to reduce the fast to three hours for solid food and alcoholic drink, and to one hour for non-alcoholic drink. Later, Pope Paul VI reduced the fast to one hour for everything.]

questions.question: What is meant by being in the grace of God?
questions.answer: To be in the grace of God means to have a pure conscience And to be free from every mortal sin.

questions.question: What should one who knows that he is in mortal sin do before receiving Communion?
questions.answer: One who knows that he is in mortal sin must make a good confession before going to Holy Communion, for even an act of perfect contrition is not enough without confession to enable one who is in mortal sin to receive Holy Communion properly.

questions.question: Why does not even an act of perfect contrition suffice to enable one who knows he is in mortal sin to go to Communion?
questions.answer: Because the Church, out of respect for this sacrament, has ordained that no one in mortal sin should dare to go to Communion without first going to confession.

questions.question: Does he who goes to Communion in mortal sin receive Jesus Christ?
questions.answer: He who goes to Communion in mortal sin receives Jesus Christ but not His grace; moreover, he commits a sacrilege and renders himself deserving of sentence of d***ation.

questions.question: What sort of fast is required before Communion?
questions.answer: Before communion there is required a natural fast which is broken by taking the least thing by way of food or drink.

questions.question: If one were to swallow a particle that had remained between the teeth, or a drop of water while washing, might he still go to Communion?
questions.answer: If one were to swallow a particle that had remained between the teeth, or a drop of water while washing, he might still go to Communion, because in both cases these things would either not be taken as food or drink, or they would have already lost the nature of either.

questions.question: Is it ever allowed to go to Communion after having broken the fast?
questions.answer: To go to Communion after having broken the fast is permitted to the sick, who are in danger of death, and to those who on account of prolonged illness have received a special dispensation from the Pope. Communion given to the sick in danger of death is called viaticum, because it supports them on their way from this life to eternity.

questions.question: What is meant by the words: To know what we are about to receive?
questions.answer: To know what we are about to receive means to know and firmly believe what is taught in Christian doctrine concerning this sacrament.

questions.question: What do the words: To receive Holy Communion with devotion mean?
questions.answer: To receive Holy Communion with devotion means to approach Holy Communion with humility and modesty in person And dress; and to make a preparation before, and an act of thanksgiving after, Holy Communion.

questions.question: In what does the preparation before Communion consist?
questions.answer: Preparation before Communion consists in meditating for some time on Whom we are about to receive, and on who we are; and in making acts of faith, hope, charity, contrition, adoration, humility, and desire to receive Jesus Christ.

questions.question: In what does the thanksgiving after Communion consist?
questions.answer: Thanksgiving after Communion consists in keeping ourselves recollected in order to honour the Lord who is within us; renewing our acts of faith, of hope, of charity, of adoration, of thanksgiving, of offerings, and of requests, especially for those graces which are most necessary for ourselves and for those for whom we are bound to pray.

questions.question: What should we do during the day on which we have received Communion?
questions.answer: During the day on which we have received Communion we should remain as recollected as possible, occupy ourselves in works of piety, and discharge the duties of our state with greater diligence.

questions.question: How long does Jesus Christ abide within us after Holy Communion?
questions.answer: After Holy Communion Jesus Christ abides within us by His grace as long as we commit no mortal sin; and He abides within us by His Real Presence until the sacramental species are consumed. #### The Way to Go to Communion

questions.question: How should we act while receiving Holy Communion?
questions.answer: In the act of receiving Holy Communion we should be kneeling, hold our head slightly raised, our eyes modest and fixed on the sacred Host, our mouth sufficiently open, and the tongue slightly out over the lips.

questions.question: How should the Communion cloth be held?
questions.answer: The Communion cloth should be held in such a way as to receive the sacred Host in case it should fall.

questions.question: When should the sacred Host be swallowed?
questions.answer: We should try to swallow the sacred Host as soon as possible, and we should avoid spitting for some time.

questions.question: If the sacred Host should cling to the palate what should be done?
questions.answer: If the sacred Host should cling to the palate it should be removed with the tongue, but never with the finger. #### The Precept of Holy Communion

questions.question: When are we bound to receive Communion?
questions.answer: We are bound to go to Communion once a year, at Easter, each one in his own parish; and also when in danger of death.

questions.question: At what age does the precept of paschal Communion begin to bind?
questions.answer: The precept of paschal Communion begins to bind as soon As a child is capable of receiving with the requisite dispositions.

questions.question: Do they sin who are old enough to receive Communion And do not?
questions.answer: They who are old enough to receive Communion and do not either because they are unwilling, or because, through their own fault, they are not instructed, undoubtedly sin. Their parents or guardians also sin if the delay of Communion is owing to their fault, and they shall have to render a strict account to God for it.

questions.question: Is it a good and useful thing to go often to Communion?
questions.answer: It is an excellent thing to go to Communion often, and even daily in accordance with the desire of the Church, provided we do so with the requisite dispositions.

questions.question: How often may we go to Holy Communion?
questions.answer: We may go to Holy Communion as often as we are advised to do so by a pious and learned confessor.

subsections.title: The Holy Sacrifice of the Mass

questions.question: Should the Holy Eucharist be considered only as a sacrament?
questions.answer: The Holy Eucharist, besides being a sacrament, is also the permanent Sacrifice of the New Law, which Jesus Christ left to His Church to be offered to God by the hands of His priests.

questions.question: In what in general does a sacrifice consist?
questions.answer: In general a sacrifice consists in the offering of some sensible thing to God and in some way destroying it as an acknowledgment of His Supreme Dominion over us and over all things.

questions.question: What is this Sacrifice of the New Law called?
questions.answer: This Sacrifice of the New Law is called the Holy Mass.

questions.question: What, then, is the Holy Mass?
questions.answer: The Holy Mass is the Sacrifice of the Body and Blood of Jesus Christ offered on our altars under the appearances of bread and wine, in commemoration of the Sacrifice of the Cross.

questions.question: Is the Sacrifice of the Mass the same as that of the Cross?
questions.answer: The Sacrifice of the Mass is substantially the same as that of the Cross, for the same Jesus Christ, Who offered Himself on the Cross, it is Who offers Himself by the hands of the priests, His ministers, on our altars; but as regards the way in which He is offered, the Sacrifice of the Mass differs from the Sacrifice of the Cross, though retaining the most intimate and essential relation to it.

questions.question: What difference and relation then is there between the Sacrifice of the Mass and that of the Cross?
questions.answer: Between the Sacrifice of the Mass and that of the Cross there is this difference and relation, that on the Cross Jesus Christ offered Himself by shedding His Blood and meriting for us; whereas on our altars He sacrifices Himself without the shedding of His Blood, and applies to us the fruits of His passion And death.

questions.question: What other relation has the Sacrifice of the Mass to that of the Cross?
questions.answer: Another relation of the Sacrifice of the Mass to that of the Cross is, that the Sacrifice of the Mass represents in a sensible way the shedding of the Blood of Jesus Christ on the Cross, because, in virtue of the words of consecration, only the Body of our Saviour is made present under the species of the bread and only His Blood under the species of the wine; although by natural concomitance and by the hypostatic union, the living And real Jesus Christ is present under each of the species.

questions.question: Is not the Sacrifice of the Cross the one only Sacrifice of the New Law?
questions.answer: The Sacrifice of the Cross is the one only Sacrifice of the New Law, inasmuch as through it Our Lord satisfied Divine Justice, acquired all the merits necessary to save us, and thus, on His part, fully accomplished our redemption. These merits, however, He applies to us through the means instituted by Him in His Church, among which is the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass.

questions.question: For what ends then is the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass offered?
questions.answer: The Sacrifice of the Mass is offered to God for four ends: (1) To honour Him properly, and hence it is called Latreutical; (2) To thank Him for His favours, and hence it is called Eucharistical; (3) To appease Him, make Him due satisfaction for our sins, and to help the souls in Purgatory, and hence it is called Propitiatory; (4) To obtain all the graces necessary for us, and hence it is called Impetratory.

questions.question: Who is it that offers to God the Sacrifice of the Holy Mass?
questions.answer: The first and principal Offeror of the Sacrifice of the Holy Mass is Jesus Christ, while the priest is the minister who in the Name of Jesus Christ offers the same Sacrifice to the Eternal Father.

questions.question: Who instituted the Sacrifice of the Holy Mass?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ Himself instituted the Sacrifice of the Holy Mass when He instituted the Sacrament of the Blessed Eucharist and said that this should be done in memory of His passion.

questions.question: To whom is the Holy Mass offered?
questions.answer: The Holy Mass is offered to God alone.

questions.question: If the Holy Mass is offered to God alone why are so many Masses celebrated in honour of the Blessed Virgin And the Saints?
questions.answer: Mass celebrated in honour of the Blessed Virgin and the Saints is always a Sacrifice offered to God alone; it is said to be celebrated in honour of the Blessed Virgin and the Saints to thank God for the gifts He has given them, and through their intercession to obtain from Him more abundantly the graces of which we have need.

questions.question: Who shares in the fruits of the Mass?
questions.answer: The entire Church shares in the fruits of the Mass, but more particularly: (1) The priest and those who assist at Mass, the latter being united with the priest; (2) Those for whom the Mass is applied, both living and dead. #### The Way to Assist at Mass

questions.question: What is required in order to assist at Holy Mass well and profitably?
questions.answer: To assist at Holy Mass well and profitably two things are necessary: (1) Modesty of person and (2) Devotion of heart.

questions.question: In what does modesty of person consist?
questions.answer: Modesty of person consists especially in being modestly dressed, in observing silence and recollection and, as far as possible, in remaining kneeling, except during the time of the two Gospels which are heard standing.

questions.question: In hearing Holy Mass which is the best way to practise true devotion?
questions.answer: In hearing Holy Mass the best way to practise true devotion is the following: (1) From the very beginning to unite our intention with that of the priest, offering the Holy Sacrifice to God for the ends for which it was instituted. (2) To accompany the priest in each prayer and action of the Sacrifice. (3) To meditate on the passion and death of Jesus Christ And to heartily detest our sins, which have been the cause of them. (4) To go to Communion, or at least to make a spiritual Communion while the priest communicates.

questions.question: What is spiritual Communion?
questions.answer: Spiritual Communion is a great desire to be united sacramentally with Jesus Christ. saying, for example: 'My Lord Jesus Christ, I desire with my whole heart to be united with Thee now and forever;' and then make the same acts that are to be made before and after sacramental Communion.

questions.question: Does the recitation of the Rosary or other prayers during Mass prevent us from hearing it with profit?
questions.answer: The recitation of the Rosary and other prayers during Mass does not prevent us from hearing it with profit, provided we try As far as possible to follow the parts of the Holy Sacrifice.

questions.question: Is it advisable to pray for others while assisting at Mass?
questions.answer: Yes it is advisable to pray for others while assisting at Mass; nay more, the time of Holy Mass is the most suitable of all times to pray for the living and the dead.

questions.question: What should we do after Mass?
questions.answer: After Mass we should give God thanks for having allowed us to assist at this great Sacrifice, and we should ask pardon for All the faults we may have committed while assisting at it.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Penance, also called Confession, is a sacrament instituted by Jesus Christ to remit the sins committed after Baptism.

questions.question: Why is the name of Penance given to this sacrament?
questions.answer: The name of Penance is given to this sacrament, because to obtain pardon for sins it is necessary to detest them penitently; and because he who has committed a fault must submit to the penance which the priest imposes.

questions.question: Why is this sacrament also called Confession?
questions.answer: This sacrament is also called Confession, because to obtain pardon for sins it is not enough to detest them, but it is necessary also to accuse oneself of them to the priest, that is, to make a confession of them.

questions.question: When did Jesus Christ institute the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ instituted the sacrament of Penance on the day of His resurrection when, entering the Supper Room, He solemnly gave His Apostles the power of remitting sin.

questions.question: How did Jesus Christ give His Apostles the power of remitting sin?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ gave His Apostles the power of remitting sin thus: Breathing upon them He said: 'Receive ye the Holy Ghost; whose sins you shall forgive they are forgiven; and whose sins you shall retain they are retained.'

questions.question: What is the matter of the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The matter of the sacrament of Penance is divided into remote and proximate. The remote matter consists of the sins committed by the penitent after Baptism; and the proximate matter are the acts of the penitent himself, that is, contrition, confession and satisfaction.

questions.question: What is the form of the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The form of the sacrament of Penance is this: 'I absolve thee from thy sins.'

questions.question: Who is the minister of the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The minister of the sacrament of Penance is a priest authorised by the Bishop to hear confessions.

questions.question: Why do you say that a priest must be authorised by the Bishop?
questions.answer: A priest must be authorised by the Bishop to hear confessions because to administer this sacrament validly the power of Orders is not enough, but there is also necessary the power of jurisdiction, that is, the power to judge, which must be given by the Bishop.

questions.question: Which are the parts of the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The parts of the sacrament of Penance are contrition, confession, and satisfaction on the part of the penitent, and absolution on the part of the priest.

questions.question: What is contrition or sorrow for sins?
questions.answer: Contrition or sorrow for sin is a grief of the soul leading us to detest sins committed and to resolve not to commit them any more.

questions.question: What does the word contrition mean?
questions.answer: Contrition means a crushing or breaking up into pieces as when a stone is hammered and reduced to dust.

questions.question: Why is the name of contrition given to sorrow for sin?
questions.answer: The name of contrition is given to sorrow for sin to signify that the hard heart of the sinner is in a certain way crushed by sorrow for having offended God.

questions.question: In what does confession of sins consist?
questions.answer: Confession of sins consists in a distinct accusation of our sins made to the confessor in order to obtain absolution and receive penance for them.

questions.question: Why is confession called an accusation?
questions.answer: Confession is called an accusation, because it must not be a careless recital, but a true and sorrowful manifestation of our sins.

questions.question: What is satisfaction or penance?
questions.answer: Satisfaction or penance is that prayer or other good work which the confessor enjoins on the penitent in expiation of his sins.

questions.question: What is absolution?
questions.answer: Absolution is the sentence which the priest pronounces in the name of Jesus Christ when remitting the penitent's sins.

questions.question: Of all the parts of the sacrament of Penance which is the most necessary?
questions.answer: Of all the parts of the sacrament of Penance the most necessary is contrition, because without it no pardon for sins is obtainable, while with it alone, perfect pardon can be obtained, provided that along with it there is the desire, at least implicit, of going to confession. #### The Effects and the Necessity of the Sacrament of Penance and the Dispositions to Receive It Properly

questions.question: Which are the effects of the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Penance confers sanctifying grace by which are remitted the mortal sins and also the venial sins which we confess and for which we are sorry; it changes eternal punishment into temporal punishment, of which it even remits more or less according to our dispositions; it revives the merits of the good works done before committing mortal sin; it gives the soul aid in due time against falling into sin again, and it restores peace of conscience.

questions.question: Is the sacrament of Penance necessary to all for salvation?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Penance is necessary for salvation to all who have committed a mortal sin after Baptism.

questions.question: Is it a good thing to go to confession often?
questions.answer: Yes, it is an excellent thing to go to confession often, because the sacrament of Penance, besides taking away sin, gives the graces necessary to avoid sin in the future.

questions.question: Has the sacrament of Penance the power of remitting all sins, no matter how numerous or how great they are?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Penance has the power of remitting all sins no matter how numerous and great they are, provided it is received with the requisite dispositions.

questions.question: How many conditions are necessary to make a good confession?
questions.answer: To make a good confession five things are necessary: (1) Examination of conscience; (2) Sorrow for having offended God; (3) A resolution of sinning no more; (4) Confession of our sins; (5) Satisfaction or penance.

questions.question: What should we do first of all to make a good confession?
questions.answer: To make a good confession we should first of all earnestly beseech God to give us light to know all our sins and strength to detest them. #### Examination of Conscience

questions.question: What is the examination of conscience?
questions.answer: The examination of conscience is a diligent search for the sins committed since the last good confession.

questions.question: How is the examination of conscience made?
questions.answer: The examination of conscience is made by carefully calling to mind before God all the sins committed but not confessed, in thought, word, deed and omission, against the Commandments of God and the Church, and against the duties of our state.

questions.question: On what else should we examine ourselves?
questions.answer: We should also examine ourselves on our bad habits and on the occasions of sin.

questions.question: In our examination should we also try to discover the number of our sins?
questions.answer: In our examination we should also try to discover the number of our mortal sins.

questions.question: What is required for a sin to be mortal?
questions.answer: For a sin to be mortal three things are required: (1) Grave matter, (2) Full advertence, (3) Perfect consent of the will.

questions.question: When is the matter to be considered grave?
questions.answer: The matter is grave when the thing under examination is seriously contrary to the laws of God and His Church.

questions.question: When is there full advertence in sinning?
questions.answer: Full advertence in sinning is had when we know perfectly well that we are doing a serious evil.

questions.question: When is perfect consent of the will verified in sinning?
questions.answer: Perfect consent of the will is verified in sinning when we deliberately determine to do a thing although we know that thing to be sinful.

questions.question: What diligence should be used in the examination of conscience?
questions.answer: In the examination of conscience the same diligence is demanded as is used in a matter of great importance.

questions.question: How much time should be spent in the examination of conscience?
questions.answer: More or less time should be spent in the examination of conscience according to the needs of each case, that is, according to the number or kind of sins that burden the conscience and according to the time that has elapsed since the last good confession.

questions.question: How may the examination of conscience be rendered easy?
questions.answer: The examination of conscience is rendered easy by making An examination of conscience every evening upon the actions of the day. #### Sorrow

questions.question: What is sorrow for sin?
questions.answer: Sorrow for sin consists in grief of soul and in a sincere detestation of the offence offered to God.

questions.question: How many kinds of sorrow are there?
questions.answer: Sorrow is of two kinds: perfect sorrow or contrition; and imperfect sorrow or attrition.

questions.question: What is perfect sorrow or contrition?
questions.answer: Perfect sorrow is a grief of soul for having offended God because He is infinitely good and worthy of being loved for His own sake.

questions.question: Why do you call the sorrow of contrition perfect sorrow?
questions.answer: I call the sorrow of contrition perfect sorrow for two reasons: (1) Because it considers the goodness of God alone and not our own advantage or loss; (2) Because it enables us at once to obtain pardon for sins, even though the obligation to confess them still remains.

questions.question: Perfect sorrow, then, obtains us pardon of our sins independently of confession?
questions.answer: Perfect sorrow does not obtain us pardon of our sins independently of confession, because it always includes the intention to confess them.

questions.question: Why does perfect sorrow or contrition produce the effect of restoring us to the grace of God?
questions.answer: Perfect sorrow or contrition produces this effect, because it proceeds from charity which cannot exist in the soul together with sin.

questions.question: What is imperfect sorrow or attrition?
questions.answer: Imperfect sorrow or attrition is that by which we repent of having offended God because He is our Supreme Judge, that is, for fear of the chastisement deserved in this life or in the life to come, or because of the very foulness of sin itself.

questions.question: What qualities must sorrow have to be true sorrow?
questions.answer: Sorrow in order to be true must have four qualities: It must be internal, supernatural, supreme and universal.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that sorrow must be internal?
questions.answer: It means that it must exist in the heart and will, and not in words alone.

questions.question: Why must sorrow be internal?
questions.answer: Sorrow must be internal because the will, which has been alienated from God by sin, must return to God by detesting the sin committed.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that sorrow must be supernatural?
questions.answer: It means that it must be excited in us by the grace of God and conceived through motives of faith.

questions.question: Why must sorrow be supernatural?
questions.answer: Sorrow must be supernatural because the end to which it is directed is supernatural, namely, God's pardon, the acquisition of sanctifying grace, and the right to eternal glory. **Explain more clearly the difference between natural and supernatural sorrow.** He who repents of having offended God because God is infinitely good and worthy of being loved for His own sake; of having lost Heaven and merited h***; or because of the intrinsic malice of sin, has supernatural sorrow, since all these are motives of faith. On the contrary, he who repents only because of the dishonour or chastisement inflicted by men, or because of some purely temporal loss, has a natural sorrow, since he repents from human motives alone.

questions.question: Why must sorrow be supreme?
questions.answer: Sorrow must be supreme because we must look upon and hate sin as the greatest of all evils, being as it is an offence against God.

questions.question: To have sorrow for sin, is it necessary to weep, as we sometimes do, in consequence of the misfortunes of this life?
questions.answer: It is not necessary to shed tears of sorrow for our sins; it is enough if in our heart we make more of having offended God than of any other misfortune whatsoever.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that sorrow must be universal?
questions.answer: It means that it must extend to every mortal sin committed.

questions.question: Why should sorrow extend to every mortal sin committed?
questions.answer: Because he who does not repent of even one mortal sin still remains an enemy to God.

questions.question: What should we do to have sorrow for our sins?
questions.answer: To have sorrow for our sins we should ask it of God with our whole heart, and excite it in ourselves by the thought of the great evil we have done by sinning.

questions.question: In going to confession should we be extremely solicitous to have a true sorrow for our sins?
questions.answer: In going to confession we should certainly be very solicitous to have a true sorrow for our sins, because this is of all things the most important; and if sorrow is wanting the confession is no good.

questions.question: If one has only venial sins to confess, must he be sorry for all of them?
questions.answer: If one has only venial sins to confess it is enough to repent of some of them for his confession to be valid; but to obtain pardon of all of them it is necessary to repent of all he remembers having committed.

questions.question: If one has only venial sins to confess and if he does not repent of even one of them, does he make a good confession?
questions.answer: If one confesses only venial sins without having sorrow for at least one of them, his confession is in vain; moreover it would be sacrilegious if the absence of sorrow was conscious.

questions.question: What should be done to render the confession of only venial sins more secure?
questions.answer: To render the confession of venial sins more secure it is prudent also to confess with true sorrow some grave sin of the past, even though it has been already confessed.

questions.question: Is it well to make an act of contrition often?
questions.answer: It is well and most useful to make an act of contrition often, especially before going to sleep or when we know we have or fear we have fallen into mortal sin, in order to recover God's grace as soon as possible; and this practice will make it easier for us to obtain from God the grace of making a like act at time of our greatest need, that is, when in danger of death. #### Resolution of Sinning No More

questions.question: In what does a good resolution consist?
questions.answer: A good resolution consists in a determined will not to commit sin for the future and to use all necessary means to avoid it.

questions.question: What conditions should a resolution have in order to be good?
questions.answer: A resolution, in order to be good, should have three principal conditions: It ought to be absolute, universal, and efficacious.

questions.question: What is meant by an absolute resolution?
questions.answer: It means that the resolution ought to be without any restrictions of time, place or person.

questions.question: What is meant by a universal resolution?
questions.answer: It means that we should avoid all mortal sins, both those already committed as well as those which we can possibly commit.

questions.question: What is meant by an efficacious resolution?
questions.answer: It means that there must be a determined will to lose everything rather than commit another sin; to avoid the dangerous occasions of sin; to stamp out our bad habits; and to discharge the obligations that may have been contracted in consequence of our sins.

questions.question: What is meant by a bad habit?
questions.answer: By a bad habit is meant an acquired disposition to fall easily into those sins to which we have become accustomed.

questions.question: What must be done to correct bad habits?
questions.answer: To correct bad habits we must watch over ourselves, pray much, go often to confession, have one good director, and put into practice the counsels and remedies which he gives us.

questions.question: What is meant by dangerous occasions of sin?
questions.answer: By dangerous occasions of sin are meant all those circumstances of time, place, person, or things, which, of their very nature or because of our frailty, lead us to commit sin.

questions.question: Are we strictly bound to shun dangerous occasions?
questions.answer: We are strictly bound to shun those dangerous occasions which ordinarily lead us to commit mortal sin, and which are called the proximate occasions of sin.

questions.question: What should a person do who cannot avoid a certain occasion of sin?
questions.answer: A person who cannot avoid a certain occasion of sin should lay the matter before his confessor and follow his advice.

questions.question: What considerations will help us to make a good resolution?
questions.answer: The same considerations help us to make a good resolution as are efficacious in exciting sorrow; that is, a consideration of the motives we have to fear God's justice and to love His infinite goodness. #### The Accusation of Sins to the Confessor

questions.question: Having prepared properly for confession by an examination of conscience, by exciting sorrow, and by forming a good resolution, what do you do next?
questions.answer: Having prepared properly for confession by an examination of conscience, by sorrow, and by a purpose of amendment, I will go to make an accusation of my sins to the confessor in order to get absolution.

questions.question: What sins are we bound to confess?
questions.answer: We are bound to confess all our mortal sins; it is well, however, to confess our venial sins also.

questions.question: Which are the qualities the accusation of sins, or confession, ought to have?
questions.answer: The principal qualities which the accusation of our sins ought to have are five: It ought to be humble, entire, sincere, prudent and brief.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the accusation ought to be humble?
questions.answer: That the accusation ought to be humble, means that the penitent should accuse himself to his confessor without pride or boasting; but with the feelings of one who is guilty, who confesses his guilt, and who appears before his judge.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the accusation ought to be entire?
questions.answer: That the accusation ought to be entire means that all mortal sins we are conscious of having committed since our last good confession must be made known, together with the circumstances and number.

questions.question: What circumstances must be made known for the accusation to be entire?
questions.answer: For the accusation to be entire, the circumstances which change the species of the sin must be made known.

questions.question: Which are the circumstances which change the species of a sin?
questions.answer: The circumstances which change the species of a sin are: (1) Those by which a sinful action from being venial becomes mortal; (2) Those by means of which a sinful action contains the malice of two or more mortal sins. **Give an example of a circumstance making a venial sin mortal.** If, to excuse himself, a man were to tell a lie and by doing so occasion serious harm to another, he would be bound to make known this circumstance, which changes the lie from an officious lie to a seriously harmful lie. **Give an example of a circumstance on account of which a single sinful action contains the malice of two or more sins.** If a man were to steal a sacred object he would be bound to accuse himself of this circumstance which adds to the theft the malice of sacrilege.

questions.question: If a penitent is not certain of having committed a sin must he confess it?
questions.answer: If a penitent is not certain of having committed a sin he is not bound to confess it; and if he does confess it, he should add that he is not certain of having committed it.

questions.question: What should he do who does not remember the exact number of his sins?
questions.answer: He who does not distinctly remember the number of his sins must mention the number as nearly as he can.

questions.question: Does he who through forgetfulness does not confess a mortal sin, or a necessary circumstance, make a good confession?
questions.answer: He who through pure forgetfulness does not confess a mortal sin, or a necessary circumstance, makes a good confession, provided he has been duly diligent in trying to remember it.

questions.question: If a mortal sin, forgotten in confession, is afterwards remembered, are we bound to confess it in another confession?
questions.answer: If a mortal sin forgotten in confession is afterwards remembered we are certainly bound to confess it the next time we go to confession.

questions.question: What does he commit who, through shame or some other motive, wilfully conceals a mortal sin in confession?
questions.answer: He who, through shame or some other motive, wilfully conceals a mortal sin in confession, profanes the sacrament and is consequently guilty of a very great sacrilege.

questions.question: In what way must he relieve his conscience who has wilfully concealed a mortal sin in confession?
questions.answer: He who has wilfully concealed a mortal sin in confession, must reveal to his confessor the sin concealed, say in how many confessions he has concealed it, and make all these confessions over again, from the last good confession.

questions.question: What reflection should a penitent make who is tempted to conceal a sin in confession?
