questions.answer: He who is tempted to conceal a mortal sin in confession should reflect: (1) That he was not ashamed to sin, in the presence of God who sees all; (2) That it is better to manifest his sin secretly to the confessor than to live tormented by sin, die an unhappy death, and be covered with shame before the whole world on the day of general judgment; (3) That the confessor is bound by the seal of confession under the gravest sin and under threat of the severest punishments both temporal and eternal.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the accusation ought to be sincere?
questions.answer: By saying that the accusation ought to be sincere, is meant that we must unfold our sins as they are, without excusing them, lessening them, or increasing them.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the confession ought to be prudent?
questions.answer: That the confession ought to be prudent, means that in confessing our sins we should use the most careful words possible and be on our guard against revealing the sins of others.

questions.question: What is meant by saying the confession ought to be short?
questions.answer: That the confession ought to be short, means that we should say nothing that is useless for the purpose of confession.

questions.question: Is it not a heavy burden to be obliged to confess one's sins to another, especially when these are shameful sins?
questions.answer: Although it may be a heavy burden to confess one's sins to another, still it must be done, because it is of divine precept, and because pardon can be obtained in no other way; and, moreover, because the difficulty is compensated by many advantages and great consolations. #### How to Make a Good Confession

questions.question: How do you present yourself to the confessor?
questions.answer: I kneel at the feet of the confessor and I say: 'Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.'

questions.question: What do you do while the confessor blesses you?
questions.answer: I humbly bow my head to receive the blessing and I make the Sign of the Cross.

questions.question: Having made the sign of the Cross what should you say?
questions.answer: Having made the sign of the Cross, I say: 'I confess to Almighty God, to blessed Mary ever Virgin, to all the Saints, and to you, my spiritual Father, that I have sinned.'

questions.question: And then what must you say?
questions.answer: Then I must say: 'I was at confession such a time; by the grace of God I received absolution, performed my penance, and went to Holy Communion.' Then I accuse myself of my sins.

questions.question: When you have finished the accusation of your sins what do you do?
questions.answer: When I have finished the accusation of my sins I say: 'I accuse myself also of all the sins of my past life, especially of those against such or such a virtue' - for example, against purity or against the Fourth Commandment, etc.

questions.question: After this accusation what should you say?
questions.answer: I should say: 'For all these sins and for those I do not remember, I ask pardon of God with my whole heart, and penance and absolution of you, my spiritual Father.'

questions.question: Having thus finished the accusation of your sins what remains to be done?
questions.answer: Having finished the accusation of my sins I should listen respectfully to what the confessor says, accept the penance with a sincere intention of performing it; and, from my heart, renew my act of contrition while he gives me absolution.

questions.question: Having received absolution what remains to be done?
questions.answer: Having received absolution I should thank the Lord, perform my penance as soon as possible, and put in practice the advice of the confessor. #### Absolution

questions.question: Must confessors always give absolution to those who go to confession to them?
questions.answer: Confessors should give absolution to those only whom they judge properly disposed to receive it.

questions.question: May confessors sometimes defer or refuse absolution?
questions.answer: Confessors not only may, but must defer or refuse absolution in certain cases So as not to profane the sacrament.

questions.question: Who are those penitents who are to be accounted badly disposed and to whom absolution must as a rule be refused or deferred?
questions.answer: Penitents who are to be accounted badly disposed are chiefly the following: (1) Those who do not know the principal mysteries of their faith, or who neglect to learn those other truths of Christian Doctrine which they are bound to know According to their state; (2) Those who are gravely negligent in examining their conscience, who show no signs of sorrow or repentance; (3) Those who are able but not willing to restore the goods of others, or the reputations they have injured; (4) Those who do not from their heart forgive their enemies; (5) Those who will not practise the means necessary to correct their bad habits; (6) Those who will not abandon the proximate occasions of sin.

questions.question: Is not a confessor too severe, who defers absolution because he does not believe the penitent is well enough disposed?
questions.answer: A confessor who defers absolution because he does not believe the penitent well enough disposed, is not too severe; on the contrary, he is very charitable and acts as a good physician who tries all remedies, even those that are disagreeable and painful, to save the life of his patient.

questions.question: Should the sinner to whom absolution is deferred or refused, despair or leave off going to confession altogether?
questions.answer: A sinner to whom absolution is deferred or refused, should not despair or leave off going to confession altogether; he should, on the contrary, humble himself, acknowledge his deplorable state, profit by the good advice his confessor gives him, and thus put himself as soon as possible in a state deserving of absolution.

questions.question: What should a penitent do with regard to selecting a confessor?
questions.answer: A genuine penitent should earnestly recommend himself to God for help to enable him to select a pious, learned, and prudent confessor, into whose hands he should put himself, obeying him as his judge and physician. #### Satisfaction or Penance

questions.question: What is satisfaction?
questions.answer: Satisfaction, which is also called sacramental penance, is one of the acts of the penitent by which he makes a certain reparation to the justice of God for his sins, by performing the works the confessor imposes on him.

questions.question: Is the penitent bound to accept the penance imposed on him by the confessor?
questions.answer: Yes, the penitent is bound to accept the penance imposed on him by the confessor if he can perform it; and if he cannot, he should humbly say so, and ask some other penance.

questions.question: When should the penance be performed?
questions.answer: If the confessor has fixed no time, the penance should be performed as soon as convenient, and as far as possible while in the state of grace.

questions.question: How should the penance be performed?
questions.answer: The penance should be performed entirely and devoutly.

questions.question: Why is a penance imposed in confession?
questions.answer: A penance is imposed because, after sacramental absolution which remits sin and its eternal punishment, there generally remains a temporal punishment to be undergone, either in this world or in Purgatory.

questions.question: Why has our Lord willed to remit all the punishment due to sin in the sacrament of Baptism, and not in the sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer: Our Lord has willed to remit all the punishment due to sin in the sacrament of Baptism, and not in the sacrament of Penance, 'because the sins after Baptism are much more grievous, being committed with fuller knowledge and greater ingratitude for God's benefits, and also in order that the obligation of satisfying for them may restrain us from falling into sin again.

questions.question: Can we of ourselves make satisfaction to God?
questions.answer: Of ourselves we cannot make satisfaction to God, but we certainly can do so by uniting ourselves to Jesus Christ, who gives value to our actions by the merits of His passion and death.

questions.question: Does the penance which the confessor imposes always suffice to discharge the punishment which remains due to our sins?
questions.answer: The penance which the confessor imposes does not ordinarily suffice to discharge the punishment remaining due to our sins; and hence we must try to supply it by other voluntary penances.

questions.question: Which are the works of penance?
questions.answer: The works of penance may be reduced to three kinds: Prayer, Fasting, and Alms-deeds.

questions.question: What is meant by prayer?
questions.answer: By prayer is meant every kind of pious exercise.

questions.question: What is meant by fasting?
questions.answer: By fasting is meant every kind of mortification.

questions.question: What is meant by almsgiving?
questions.answer: By almsgiving is meant every spiritual or corporal work of mercy.

questions.question: Which penance is the more meritorious, that which the confessor gives, or that which we do of our own choice?
questions.answer: The penance which the confessor imposes is the most meritorious, because being part of the sacrament it receives greater virtue from the merits of the passion of Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Do those who die after having received absolution but before they have fully satisfied the justice of God, go straight to Heaven?
questions.answer: No, they go to Purgatory there to satisfy the justice of God and be perfectly purified.

questions.question: Can the souls in Purgatory be relieved of their pains by us?
questions.answer: Yes, the souls in Purgatory can be relieved by our prayers, alms-deeds, all our other good works, and by indulgences, but above all by the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass.

questions.question: Besides his penance, what else must the penitent do after confession?
questions.answer: Besides performing his penance after confession, the penitent, if he has justly injured another in his goods or reputation, or if he has given him scandal, must as soon as possible, and as far as he is able, restore him his goods, repair his honour, and remedy the scandal.

questions.question: How can the scandal given be remedied?
questions.answer: The scandal given can be remedied by removing the occasion of it and by edifying by word and example those whom we have scandalised.

questions.question: How should we make satisfaction to one whom we have offended?
questions.answer: We should make satisfaction to one whom we have offended, by asking his pardon, or by some other suitable reparation.

questions.question: What fruits does a good confession produce in us?
questions.answer: A good confession: (1) Remits the sins we have committed and gives us the grace of God; (2) Restores us peace and quiet of conscience; (3) Reopens the gates of Heaven and changes the eternal punishment of h*** into a temporal punishment; (4) Preserves us from falling again, and renders us capable of partaking of the treasury of Indulgences.

questions.question: What is an Indulgence?
questions.answer: An Indulgence is the remission of the temporal punishment due on account of our sins which have been already pardoned as far as their guilt is concerned - a remission accorded by the Church outside the sacrament of Penance.

questions.question: From whom has the Church received the power to grant Indulgences?
questions.answer: The Church has received the power to grant Indulgences from Jesus Christ.

questions.question: In what way does the Church by means of Indulgences remit this temporal punishment?
questions.answer: The Church by means of Indulgences remits this temporal punishment by applying to us the superabundant merits of Jesus Christ, of the Blessed Virgin and of the Saints, which constitute what is known as the Treasure of the Church.

questions.question: Who has the power to grant Indulgences?
questions.answer: The Pope alone has the power to grant Indulgences in the whole Church, and the Bishop in his own diocese, according to the faculty given him by the Pope.

questions.question: How many kinds of Indulgences are there?
questions.answer: Indulgences are of two kinds: plenary and partial.

questions.question: What is a plenary Indulgence?
questions.answer: A plenary Indulgence is that by which the whole temporal punishment due to our sins is remitted. Hence, if one were to die after having gained such an Indulgence, he would go straight to Heaven, being, as he is, perfectly exempt from the pains of Purgatory.

questions.question: What is a partial Indulgence?
questions.answer: A partial Indulgence is that by which is remitted only a part of the temporal punishment due to our sins.

questions.question: Why does the Church grant Indulgences?
questions.answer: In granting Indulgences the Church intends to aid our incapacity to expiate all the temporal punishment in this world, by enabling us to obtain by means of works of piety and Christian charity that which in the first ages Christians gained by the rigour of Canonical penances.

questions.question: What is meant by an Indulgence of forty or a hundred days or of seven years, and the like?
questions.answer: By an Indulgence of forty or a hundred days, or of seven years and the like, is meant the remission of so much of the temporal punishment as would have been paid by penances of forty or a hundred days, or seven years, anciently prescribed in the Church.

questions.question: What value should we set on Indulgences?
questions.answer: We should set the greatest value on Indulgences because by them we satisfy the justice of God and obtain possession of Heaven sooner and more easily.

questions.question: Which are the conditions necessary to gain Indulgences?
questions.answer: The conditions necessary to gain Indulgences are: (1) The state of grace (at least at the final completion of the work), and freedom from those venial faults, the punishment of which we wish to cancel; (2) The fulfilment of all the works the Church enjoins in order to gain the Indulgence; (3) The intention to gain it.

questions.question: Can Indulgences be applied also to the souls in Purgatory?
questions.answer: Yes, Indulgences can be applied also to the souls in Purgatory, when he who grants them says that they may be so applied.

questions.question: What is a Jubilee?
questions.answer: A Jubilee, which as a rule is granted every twenty-five years, is a Plenary Indulgence to which are attached many privileges and special concessions, such as that of being able to obtain absolution from certain reserved sins and from censures, and the commutation of certain vows.

questions.question: What is Extreme Unction?
questions.answer: Extreme Unction is a sacrament instituted for the spiritual as well as for the temporal comfort of the sick in danger of death.

questions.question: What are the effects of Extreme Unction?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Extreme Unction produces the following effects: (1) It increases sanctifying grace; (2) It remits venial sins, and also mortal sins which the sick person, if contrite, is unable to confess; (3) It takes away weakness and sloth which remain even After pardon has been obtained; (4) It gives strength to bear illness patiently, to withstand temptation and to die holily; (5) It aids in restoring us to health of body if it is for the good of the soul.

questions.question: When should Extreme Unction be received?
questions.answer: Extreme Unction should be received when the illness is dangerous, and after the sick person has received, if possible, the sacraments of Penance and the Blessed Eucharist; it is even well to receive it while he has the use of his senses, and has still some hope of recovery.

questions.question: Why is it well to receive Extreme Unction when the sick person has still the use of his senses, and has still some hope of recovery?
questions.answer: It is well to receive Extreme Unction while the sick person retains the use of his senses, and while there remains some hope of his recovery because: (1) He thus receives it with better dispositions, and is hence able to derive greater fruit from it; (2) This sacrament restores health of body (should it be for the good of the soul) by assisting the powers of nature; and hence it should not be deferred until recovery is despaired of.

questions.question: With what dispositions should the sacrament of Extreme Unction be received?
questions.answer: The principal dispositions for receiving Extreme Unction are: To be in the state of grace; to have confidence in the power of this sacrament and in the mercy of God and to be resigned to the will of the Lord.

questions.question: What should be the sick person's feelings on seeing the priest?
questions.answer: On seeing the priest, the sick person should feel thankful to God for having sent him; and should gladly receive the comforts of religion, which, if he is able, he should request himself.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of Holy Orders?
questions.answer: Holy Orders is a sacrament which gives power to exercise the sacred duties connected with the worship of God and the salvation of souls, and which imprints the character of Minister of God on the soul of him who receives it.

questions.question: Why is it called Orders?
questions.answer: It is called Orders because it comprises various grades, the one subordinate to the other, from which the sacred Hierarchy is composed.

questions.question: Which are these grades?
questions.answer: The highest is the Episcopate, which contains the fullness of the Priesthood; then comes the Priesthood; then the Diaconate, the Sub-diaconate, and the Orders called Minor.

questions.question: When did Jesus Christ institute the Sacerdotal Order?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ instituted the Sacerdotal Order at the Last Supper when he conferred on the Apostles and their successors the power of consecrating the Blessed Eucharist. Then on the day of His resurrection He conferred on them the power of remitting and retaining sin, thus constituting them the first Priests of the New Law in all the fullness of their power.

questions.question: Who is the Minister of this sacrament?
questions.answer: The bishop is the Minister of this sacrament.

questions.question: Is the dignity of the Christian Priesthood a great dignity?
questions.answer: The dignity of the Christian Priesthood is great indeed, because of the two-fold power which Jesus Christ has conferred upon it - that over His real body and that over His mystical body, or the Church; and because of the divine mission committed to priests to lead men to eternal life.

questions.question: Is the Catholic Priesthood necessary in the Church?
questions.answer: The Catholic Priesthood is necessary in the Church, because without it the faithful would be deprived of the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass and of the greater part of the sacraments; they would have no one to instruct them in the faith; and they would be as sheep without a shepherd, a prey to wolves; in short, the Church, such as Christ instituted it, would no longer exist.

questions.question: Will the Catholic Priesthood therefore never cease on this earth?
questions.answer: In spite of the war that h*** wages against it, the Catholic Priesthood will last until the end of time, because Jesus Christ has promised that the powers of h*** shall never prevail against His Church.

questions.question: Is it a sin to despise Priests?
questions.answer: It is a very grave sin, because the scorn and insults cast on Priests fall upon Jesus Christ Himself, who said to His Apostles: He who despises you, despises Me.

questions.question: What motive should he have who embraces the ecclesiastical state?
questions.answer: The motive of one who embraces the ecclesiastical state should be the glory of God and the salvation of souls alone.

questions.question: What is necessary to enter the ecclesiastical state?
questions.answer: To enter the ecclesiastical state a divine vocation is necessary before all else.

questions.question: What should be done to find out whether God calls us to the ecclesiastical state?
questions.answer: To find out if God calls us to the ecclesiastical state we should: (1) Fervently pray the Lord to make known His will to us; (2) Consult our Bishop or a learned and prudent director; (3) Diligently examine whether we have the capacity necessary for the studies, the duties, and the obligations of this state.

questions.question: If one were to enter the ecclesiastical state without a divine vocation would he do wrong?
questions.answer: If one were to enter the ecclesiastical state without a divine vocation he would commit a great wrong and run the risk of being lost.

questions.question: Do those parents sin who, from worldly motives, impel their sons to embrace the ecclesiastical state without any vocation?
questions.answer: Those parents who, for worldly motives, impel their sons to embrace the ecclesiastical state without any vocation commit a very grave sin, because by thus acting they usurp the right God has reserved to Himself alone of choosing His own ministers; and they expose their children to the danger of eternal d***ation.

questions.question: Which are the duties of the faithful towards those who are called to Holy Orders?
questions.answer: The faithful should: (1) Give their children and dependents full liberty to follow the call of God; (2) Pray God to deign to grant good pastors and zealous ministers to His Church - it is precisely for this end that the fasts of Quarter Tense have been instituted; (3) Have special respect for all who are consecrated by Holy Orders to God's service.

questions.question: What is the sacrament of Matrimony?
questions.answer: Matrimony is a sacrament, instituted by our Lord Jesus Christ, which creates a holy and indissoluble union between a man and woman, and gives them grace to love one another holily and to bring up their children as Christians.

questions.question: By whom was Matrimony instituted?
questions.answer: Matrimony was instituted by God Himself in the Garden of Paradise, and was raised to the dignity of a sacrament by Jesus Christ in the New Law.

questions.question: Has the sacrament of Matrimony any special signification?
questions.answer: The sacrament of Matrimony signifies the indissoluble union of Jesus Christ with the Church, His Spouse, and our holy Mother.

questions.question: Why do we say that the bond of marriage is indissoluble?
questions.answer: We say that the bond of marriage is indissoluble or that it cannot be dissolved except by the death of either husband or wife, because God so ordained from the beginning and so Jesus Christ our Lord solemnly proclaimed.

questions.question: Can the contract be separated from the sacrament in Christian marriage?
questions.answer: No, in marriage among Christians the contract cannot be separated from the sacrament, because, for Christians, marriage is nothing else than the natural contract itself, raised by Jesus Christ to the dignity of a Sacrament.

questions.question: Among Christians, then, there can be no true marriage that is not a Sacrament?
questions.answer: Among Christians there can be no true marriage that is not a sacrament.

questions.question: What effects does the sacrament of Matrimony produce?
questions.answer: The sacrament of matrimony: (1) Gives an increase of sanctifying grace; (2) Gives a special grace for the faithful discharge of all the duties of the married state. #### Minister - Rite Dispositions

questions.question: Who are the Ministers of this sacrament?
questions.answer: The Ministers of this sacrament are the couple themselves, who together confer and receive the sacrament.

questions.question: How is this sacrament administered?
questions.answer: This sacrament, preserving, as it does, the nature of a contract, is administered by the contracting parties. themselves, who declare, in the presence of the parish priest, or another priest delegated by him, and of two witnesses, that they take each other in marriage.

questions.question: What use, then, is the blessing which the parish priest gives to the married couple?
questions.answer: The blessing which the parish priest gives to the married couple is not necessary to constitute the sacrament, but it is given to sanction their union in the name of the Church and to invoke on them more abundantly the blessing of God.

questions.question: What intention should those have who contract marriage?
questions.answer: Those who contract marriage should have the intention: (1) Of doing the will of God, who calls them to that state; (2) Of working out in that state the salvation of their souls; (3) Of bringing up their children as Christians, if God should bless them with any.

questions.question: How should those about to be married prepare themselves to receive this Sacrament with fruit?
questions.answer: In order to receive this sacrament with fruit, those about to be married should: (1) Earnestly recommend themselves to God, so as to know His will and obtain the graces necessary for that state; (2) Consult their parents before making any promise, because obedience and the respect due to them demand this; (3) Prepare themselves by a good confession, or, if necessary, a general confession of their whole life; (4) Avoid all dangerous familiarity in word or act while in each other's company.

questions.question: Which are the principal obligations of married persons?
questions.answer: Married persons should: (1) Guard inviolably their conjugal fidelity and behave Always and in all things as Christians; (2) Love one another, bear patiently with one another, and live in peace and concord; (3) Think seriously of providing for their children, if they have any, according to their needs; bring them up as Christians, and leave them free to choose the state of life to which they are called by God. #### Conditions and Impediments

questions.question: What is necessary to contract Christian marriage validly?
questions.answer: To contract Christian marriage validly it is necessary to be free from every diriment impediment to marriage; and to give consent freely to the marriage contract in the presence of the parish priest (or a priest delegated by him) and of two witnesses.

questions.question: What is necessary to contract marriage lawfully?
questions.answer: To contract marriage lawfully it is necessary to be free from every impeding impediment to marriage; to be instructed in the principal truths of religion; and, finally, to be in a state of grace; otherwise a sacrilege would be committed.

questions.question: What are impediments to marriage?
questions.answer: Impediments to marriage are certain circumstances which render marriage either invalid or unlawful. The former are called diriment impediments and the latter impeding impediments. **Give examples of diriment impediments.** Diriment impediments are, for example, relationship to the fourth degree, spiritual relationship, a solemn vow of chastity, or difference in religion, that is, when one party is baptised and the other is not. [This has been altered by the 1983 code of canon law] **Give examples of impeding impediments.** Impeding impediments are, for example, the forbidden times, a simple vow of chastity, and the like.

questions.question: Are the faithful obliged to make known to ecclesiastical authority impediments of which they have a knowledge?
questions.answer: The faithful are obliged to make known to ecclesiastical authority impediments of which they have knowledge; and for this reason the names of those who intend to get married are published in the Church.

questions.question: Who has the power to regulate impediments to marriage, to dispense from them, and to judge of the validity of Christian marriage?
questions.answer: The Church alone has power to regulate impediments to marriage, to judge of the validity of marriage among Christians and to dispense from the impediments which she has placed.

questions.question: Why has the Church alone power to place impediments and to judge of the validity of marriage?
questions.answer: The Church alone has power to place impediments, to judge of the validity of marriage, and to dispense from the impediments which she has placed, because the contract, being inseparable from the sacrament in a Christian marriage, also comes under the power of the Church, to which alone Jesus Christ gave the right to make laws and give decisions in sacred things.

questions.question: Can the civil authority dissolve the bonds of Christian marriage by divorce?
questions.answer: No, the bond of Christian marriage cannot be dissolved by the civil authority, because the civil authority cannot interfere with the matter of the sacrament nor can it put asunder what God has joined together.

questions.question: What is a civil marriage?
questions.answer: It is nothing but a mere formality prescribed by the [civil] law to give and insure the civil effects of the marriage to the spouses and their children.

questions.question: Is it sufficient for a Christian to get only the civil marriage or contract?
questions.answer: For a Christian, it is not sufficient to get only the civil contract, because it is not a sacrament, and therefore not a true marriage.

questions.question: In what condition would the spouses be who would live together united only by a civil marriage?
questions.answer: Spouses who would live together united by only a civil marriage would be in an habitual state of mortal sin, and their union would always be illegitimate in the sight of God and of the Church.

questions.question: Should we also get the civil marriage?
questions.answer: We should perform the civil marriage, because, though it is not a sacrament, it provides the spouses and their children with the civil effects of conjugal society; for this reason, the ecclesiastical authority as a general rule allows the religious marriage only after the formalities prescribed by the civil authorities have been accomplished. [In many countries, especially English speaking countries, the civil authority acknowledges the religious marriage and gives it the civil effects, thus there is no need of a separate ceremony. However the states often add certain requirements and formalities which should be observed.]

sections.title: On the Commandments of God and of the Church

subsections.title: The Commandments of God in General

questions.question: What is treated of in the third part of Christian Doctrine?
questions.answer: The Commandments of God and of the Church are treated of in the third part of Christian Doctrine.

questions.question: How many Commandments of God's Law are there?
questions.answer: There are Ten Commandments of God's Law: I am the Lord thy God: 1. Thou shalt not have strange gods before Me; 2. Thou shalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain; 3. Remember thou keep holy the Sabbath Day; 4. Honour thy Father and thy Mother, 5. Thou shalt not kill; 6. Thou shalt not commit adultery; 7. Thou shalt not steal; 8. Thou shalt not bear false witness; 9. Thou shalt not covet another's wife; 10. Thou shalt not covet another's goods.

questions.question: Why are the Commandments of God so named?
questions.answer: The Commandments of God are so named because God Himself has stamped them on the soul of every man; promulgated them, engraved on two tables of stone, on Mount Sinai, in the Old Law; and Jesus Christ has confirmed them in the New Law.

questions.question: Which are the Commandments of the first table?
questions.answer: The Commandments of the first table are the first three, which directly regard God and our duties towards Him.

questions.question: Which are the Commandments of the second table?
questions.answer: The Commandments of the second table are the last seven, which regard our neighbour, and our duties towards him.

questions.question: Are we bound to observe the Commandments?
questions.answer: Yes, we are bound to observe the Commandments, because we are all bound to live according to the will of God who created us, and because a serious transgression against even one of them is enough to merit h***.

questions.question: Are we able to observe the Commandments?
questions.answer: Yes, without doubt we are able to observe God's Commandments, because God never commands anything that is impossible, and because He gives grace to observe them to those who ask it as they should.

questions.question: What, in a general way, should we consider in each of the Commandments?
questions.answer: In each of the Commandments we should consider its positive part and its negative part, that is, what it commands and what it forbids.

questions.question: Why is it said at the commencement of the Commandments: I am the Lord thy God?
questions.answer: It is said at the commencement of the Commandments: I am the Lord thy God, to show us that God being our Creator and Lord, can command whatever He wills, and that we, being His creatures, are bound to obey Him.

questions.question: In the words of the First Commandment: Thou shalt not have strange gods before Me, what does God command us?
questions.answer: By the words of the First Commandment: Thou shalt not have strange gods before Me, He commands us to acknowledge, adore, love and serve Him alone as our Sovereign Lord.

questions.question: How do we fulfil the First Commandment?
questions.answer: We fulfil the First Commandment by the practice of internal and external worship.

questions.question: What is internal worship?
questions.answer: Internal worship is the honour which is given to God with the faculties of the soul alone, that is with the intellect and the will.

questions.question: What is external worship?
questions.answer: External worship is the homage that is given to God by means of outward acts and of sensible objects.

questions.question: Is it not enough internally to adore God with the heart alone?
questions.answer: No, it is not enough internally to adore God with the heart alone; we must also adore Him externally with both soul and body, because He is the Creator and absolute Lord of both.

questions.question: Can there be external worship without internal worship?
questions.answer: No, in no way can there be external worship without internal, because unless external worship is accompanied by internal, it is destitute of life, of merit, and of efficacy, like a body without a soul.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the First Commandment?
questions.answer: The First Commandment forbids idolatry, superstition, sacrilege, heresy, and every other sin against religion.

questions.question: What is idolatry?
questions.answer: Idolatry is the giving to any creature, for example, to a statue, to an image, or to a man, the supreme worship of adoration that belongs to God alone.

questions.question: How is this prohibition expressed in Holy Scripture?
questions.answer: This prohibition is expressed in Holy Scripture in these words: Thou shalt not make to thyself a graven thing, nor the likeness of anything that is in heaven above, or on the earth beneath; and thou shalt not adore them or serve them.

questions.question: Do these words forbid every kind of image?
questions.answer: Certainly not; but only those of false divinities, made to be adored, as idolaters adore them. So true is this, that God Himself commanded Moses to make images, as, for example, the two statues of the Cherubim for the Ark, and the Brazen Serpent in the desert.

questions.question: What is superstition?
questions.answer: Superstition is any devotion that is contrary to the teaching and practice of the Church; as also the ascribing to any action or any thing whatever a supernatural virtue which it does not possess.

questions.question: What is a sacrilege?
questions.answer: A sacrilege is the profanation of a place, of a person, or of a thing consecrated to God and set apart for his worship.

questions.question: What is heresy?
questions.answer: Heresy is a culpable error of the intellect by which some truth of faith is obstinately denied.

questions.question: What else does the First Commandment forbid?
questions.answer: The First Commandment also forbids all dealings with the devil, and all association with anti-Christian sects.

questions.question: If one were to have recourse to and invoke the devil, would he commit a grave sin?
questions.answer: If one were to have recourse to and invoke the devil, he would commit an enormous sin, because the devil is the most wicked enemy both of God and of man.

questions.question: Is it lawful to put questions to speaking or writing tables or in any way to consult the souls of the dead by means of spiritism?
questions.answer: All the practices of spiritism are unlawful, because they are superstitious; and often they are not free from diabolical intervention; and hence they are rightly condemned by the Church.

questions.question: Does the First Commandment forbid us to honour and invoke the Angels and Saints?
questions.answer: No, it is not forbidden to honour and invoke the Angels and Saints; on the contrary, we should do so, because it is a good and useful practice highly commended by the Church; for they are God's friends and our intercessors with Him.

questions.question: Since Jesus Christ is our only mediator with God, why have recourse also to the intercession of the Blessed Virgin and the Saints?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ is our Mediator with God, because being true God and true man He alone in virtue of His own merits has reconciled us to God and obtains us all graces. But in virtue of the merits of Jesus Christ, and through the charity which unites them to God and us, the Blessed Virgin and the Saints help us by their intercession to obtain the graces we ask. And this is one of the great benefits of the Communion of Saints.

questions.question: May we also honour the sacred images of Jesus Christ and of the Saints?
questions.answer: Yes, because the honour we give the sacred images of Jesus Christ and of the Saints is referred to their very persons.

questions.question: May the relics of the Saints be honoured?
questions.answer: Yes, we should honour the relics of the Saints, because their bodies were living members of Jesus Christ and temples of the Holy Ghost, and will rise gloriously to eternal life.

questions.question: What is the difference between the honour we give to God and the honour we give to the Saints?
questions.answer: Between the honour we give to God and the honour we give to the Saints there is this difference, that we adore God because of his infinite excellence, whereas we do not adore the Saints, but honour and venerate them as God's friends and our intercessors with Him. The honour we give to God is called Latria, that is, the worship of adoration; the honour we give to the Saints is called Dulia, that is, the veneration of the servants of God; while the special honour we give to the Blessed Virgin is called Hyperdulia, that is, a special veneration of the Mother of God.

questions.question: What does the Second Commandment: Thou shalt not take the Name of God in vain, forbid?
questions.answer: The Second Commandment: Thou shalt not take the Name of God in vain, forbids us: (1) To utter the Name of God irreverently; (2) To blaspheme God, the Blessed Virgin or the Saints; (3) To take false, unnecessary, or unlawful oaths.

questions.question: What is meant by: Not to utter the Name of God irreverently?
questions.answer: Not to utter the Name of God irreverently means not to mention this Holy Name, or any other name that in a special way refers to God Himself, such as the name of Jesus, of Mary and the Saints, in anger or in joke or in any irreverent way whatsoever.

questions.question: What is blasphemy?
questions.answer: Blasphemy is a horrible sin which consists in words or acts of contempt or malediction against God, the Blessed Virgin, the Saints, or sacred things.

questions.question: Is there any difference between blasphemy and imprecation?
questions.answer: There is a difference, because by blasphemy one wishes evil to or curses God, the Blessed Virgin or the Saints; while by imprecation one wishes evil to or curses one's self or one's neighbour.

questions.question: What is an oath?
questions.answer: An oath is the calling on God to witness the truth of what one says or promises.

questions.question: Is it always forbidden to take an oath?
questions.answer: It is not always forbidden to take an oath; an oath is lawful and even gives honour to God, when it is necessary, and when one swears with truth, judgement and justice.

questions.question: When is an oath without truth?
questions.answer: When one affirms on oath what he knows or believes to be false, or when one promises under oath to do what one has no intention of doing.

questions.question: When is an oath without judgement?
questions.answer: When one makes oaths imprudently and without mature consideration, or in trivial matters.

questions.question: When is an oath without justice?
questions.answer: When one makes an oath to do something unjust or unlawful, as, for example, to swear to take revenge, or to steal, and so on.

questions.question: Are we obliged to keep an oath to do unjust or unlawful things?
questions.answer: Not only are we not obliged, but we should sin by doing such things, because they are forbidden by the laws of God and of the Church.

questions.question: What sin does he commit who swears falsely?
questions.answer: He who swears falsely commits a mortal sin, because he grievously dishonours God, the Infinite Truth, by calling Him to witness what is false.

questions.question: What does the Second Commandment command us to do?
questions.answer: The Second Commandment commands us to honour the Holy Name of God as well as to keep our oaths and vows.

questions.question: What is a vow?
questions.answer: A vow is a promise made to God regarding something which is good, within our power, and better than its opposite, and to the keeping of which we bind ourselves just as if it had been commanded us.

questions.question: If the keeping of a vow were to become very difficult, in whole or in part, what is to be done?
questions.answer: Commutation or dispensation, may be sought from one's Bishop or from the Pope, according to the character of the vow.

questions.question: Is it a sin to break a vow?
questions.answer: It is a sin to break a vow and therefore we should not make vows without mature reflection, nor, as a rule, without the advice of our confessor or other prudent person, so as not to expose ourselves to the danger of sinning.

questions.question: May vows be made to our Lady and the Saints?
questions.answer: Vows are made to God alone; we may, however, promise God to do something in honour of our Lady or the Saints.

questions.question: What does the Third Commandment: Remember thou keep holy the Sabbath day, command us to do?
questions.answer: The Third Commandment: Remember thou keep holy the Sabbath day, commands us to honour God by acts of worship on festivals.

questions.question: What are festivals?
questions.answer: In the Old Law they were Saturdays and certain other days regarded as specially solemn by the Jews; in the New Law they are Sundays and other festivals instituted by the Church.

questions.question: Why is Sunday sanctified instead of Saturday in the New Law?
questions.answer: Sunday, which means the Lord's Day, was substituted for Saturday, because it was on that day that our Lord rose from the dead.

questions.question: What act of worship is commanded us on festivals?
questions.answer: We are commanded to assist devoutly at the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass.

questions.question: With what other good works does a good Christian sanctify festivals?
questions.answer: A good Christian sanctifies festivals: (1) By attending Christian Doctrine, sermons, and the Divine Office; (2) By frequently and devoutly receiving the sacraments of Penance and the Blessed Eucharist; (3) By the practice of prayer and works of Christian charity.

questions.question: What does the Third Commandment forbid?
questions.answer: The Third Commandment forbids servile works and any other works that hinder the worship of God.

questions.question: What servile works are forbidden on festivals?
questions.answer: The servile works forbidden on festivals are those works called manual, that is, those material works in which the body has more part than the mind, such, for instance, as are ordinarily done by servants, labourers, and artisans.

questions.question: What sin does one commit by working on festivals?
questions.answer: One commits a mortal sin by working on festivals; brevity of time, however, will excuse from grave sin.

questions.question: Is no servile work at all permitted on festivals?
questions.answer: On festivals those works are permitted which are necessary for life, or for the service of God; as well as those done for a grave reason, with leave, when possible, from the Pastor.

questions.question: Why is servile work forbidden on festivals?
questions.answer: Servile work is forbidden on festivals in order that we may the better attend to divine worship, and to the care of our souls; And to enable us to rest from toil. Hence innocent recreation is not forbidden.

questions.question: What else above all should we avoid on festivals?
questions.answer: We should above all avoid sin and whatever leads to sin, such as dangerous diversions and dangerous places of amusement.

questions.question: What does the Fourth Commandment: Honour thy father and thy mother, command?
questions.answer: The Fourth Commandment: Honour thy father and thy mother, commands us to respect our parents, obey them in all that is not sinful, and assist them in their temporal and spiritual needs.

questions.question: What does the Fourth Commandment forbid?
questions.answer: The Fourth Commandment forbids us to offend our parents by word or by deed or in any other way.

questions.question: What other persons does this Commandment include under the names of father and mother?
questions.answer: Under the names of father and mother this Commandment also includes all our superiors, both ecclesiastical and lay, whom we must consequently obey and respect.

questions.question: Whence are derived the authority of parents to command their children and the duty of children to obey their parents?
questions.answer: The authority possessed by parents to command their children and the obligation children are under to obey their parents, are derived from God who constituted and established family life in order that in it man might have the first helps that are necessary towards his spiritual and temporal well-being.

questions.question: Have parents any duties towards their children?
questions.answer: Parents are bound to love, support and maintain their children; to attend to their religious and secular education; to give them good example; to keep them from the occasions of sin; to correct their faults; and to help them to embrace the state to which God has called them.

questions.question: Has God given us an example of a perfect family?
questions.answer: God gave us an example of a perfect family in the Holy Family in which Jesus Christ lived subject to the Blessed Virgin and Saint Joseph until His thirtieth year, that is, until He began the Mission of preaching the Gospel entrusted to Him by His Eternal Father.

questions.question: If families were to live alone, cut off one from the other, could they provide for all their material and moral needs?
questions.answer: If families lived alone, cut off one from the other, they could not provide for their individual needs, and hence it is necessary that they be united in civil society so as mutually to aid one another for the common good and happiness.

questions.question: What is Civil Society?
questions.answer: Civil Society is the union of many families under the authority of one head for the purpose of assisting each other in securing their mutual perfection and temporal happiness.

questions.question: Whence comes the authority which rules Civil Society?
questions.answer: The authority which rules Civil Society comes from God, who established it for the common good.

questions.question: Are we under any obligation to obey the authority that governs Civil Society?
questions.answer: Yes; all who form part of Civil Society are bound to respect and obey authority because that authority comes from God and because the common good so demands.

questions.question: Are all laws imposed by the Civil Authority to be respected?
questions.answer: Yes; in accordance with the command and example of our Lord Jesus Christ, all laws imposed by the Civil Authority are to be respected, provided they are not contrary to the law of God.

questions.question: Have those who form part of Civil Society any other duties besides respect and obedience to the laws imposed by authority?
questions.answer: Besides the obligation of respect and obedience to the laws, all those who form part of Civil Society are bound to live in peace, and to endeavour, each according to his means and ability, to render that society virtuous, peaceful, orderly and prosperous.

questions.question: What does the Fifth Commandment: Thou shalt not kill, forbid?
questions.answer: The Fifth Commandment, Thou shalt not kill, forbids us to kill, strike, wound or do any other bodily harm to our neighbour, either of ourselves or by the agency of others; as also to wish him evil, or to offend him by injurious language. In this Commandment God also forbids the taking of one's own life, or suicide.

questions.question: Why is it a grave sin to kill one's neighbour?
questions.answer: Because the slayer unjustly invades the right which God alone has over the life of man; because he destroys the security of civil society; and because he deprives his neighbour of life, which is the greatest natural good on earth.

questions.question: Are there cases in which it is lawful to kill?
questions.answer: It is lawful to kill when fighting in a just war; when carrying out by order of the Supreme Authority a sentence of death in punishment of a crime; and, finally, in cases of necessary and lawful defence of one's own life against an unjust aggressor.

questions.question: Does God also forbid us in the Fifth Commandment to do harm to the spiritual life of another?
questions.answer: Yes, in the Fifth Commandment God also forbids us to do harm to another's spiritual life by scandal.

questions.question: What is scandal?
questions.answer: Scandal is any word, act, or omission which is the occasion of another's committing sin.

questions.question: Is scandal a grave sin?
questions.answer: Scandal is a grave sin because, by causing the loss of souls, it tends to destroy the greatest work of God, namely, the redemption; it effects the death of another's soul by depriving it of the life of grace, which is more precious than the life of the body; and is the source of a multitude of sins. Hence God threatens the severest chastisement to those who give scandal.

questions.question: Why does God, in the Fifth Commandment, forbid the taking of one's own life or suicide?
questions.answer: In the Fifth Commandment God forbids suicide, because man is not the master of his own life no more than of the life of another. Hence the Church punishes suicide by deprivation of Christian burial.

questions.question: Is duelling also forbidden by the Fifth Commandment?
questions.answer: Yes, duelling is also forbidden by the Fifth Commandment, because duelling has in it the guilt both of suicide and of homicide; and whoever voluntarily takes part in it, even as a simple onlooker, is excommunicated.

questions.question: Is duelling also forbidden when there is no danger of being killed?
questions.answer: This sort of duelling is also forbidden, because not only are we forbidden to kill, but even voluntarily to wound ourselves or others.

questions.question: Is the defence of one's honour an excuse for duelling?
questions.answer: No, because it is not true that the offence is repaired by duelling; and because honour cannot be repaired by an unjust, irrational and barbarous act such as duelling.

questions.question: What does the Fifth Commandment command?
questions.answer: The Fifth Commandment commands us to forgive our enemies and to wish well to all.

questions.question: What should he do who has injured another in the life of either body or soul?
questions.answer: He who has injured another must not only confess his sin, but must also repair the harm by compensating his neighbour for the loss he has sustained, by retracting the errors taught, and by giving good example.

questions.question: What does the Sixth Commandment, Thou shalt not commit adultery, forbid?
questions.answer: The Sixth Commandment, Thou shalt not commit adultery, forbids every act, every look and every word contrary to chastity; it also forbids infidelity in marriage.

questions.question: What does the Ninth Commandment forbid?
questions.answer: The Ninth Commandment expressly forbids every desire contrary to that fidelity which husband and wife vowed to observe when contracting marriage; and it also forbids every guilty thought or desire of anything that is prohibited by the Sixth Commandment.

questions.question: Is impurity a great sin?
questions.answer: It is a most grave and abominable sin in the sight of God and man; it lowers man to the condition of the brute; it drags him into many other sins and vices; and it provokes the most terrible chastisements both in this world and in the next.

questions.question: Is every thought that comes into the mind against purity a sin?
questions.answer: The thoughts that come into the mind against purity are not of themselves sins, but rather temptations and incentives to sin.

questions.question: When is a bad thought a sin?
questions.answer: Bad thoughts, even though resulting in no bad deed, are sins when we culpably entertain them, or consent to them, or expose ourselves to the proximate danger of consenting to them.

questions.question: What do the Sixth and Ninth Commandments command?
questions.answer: The Sixth Commandment commands us to be chaste and modest in act, in look, in behaviour, and in speech. The Ninth Commandment commands us in addition to this to be chaste and pure interiorly, that is, in mind and in heart.

questions.question: What must we do to observe the Sixth and Ninth Commandments?
questions.answer: To be able to observe the Sixth and Ninth Commandments, we ought to pray often and from our hearts to God; be devout to the Blessed Virgin, the Mother of purity; remember that God watches us; think on death, on the Divine chastisements, and on the Passion of Jesus Christ; guard the senses; practice Christian mortification; and frequent the Sacraments with the proper dispositions.

questions.question: What must we avoid in order to preserve ourselves chaste?
questions.answer: To preserve ourselves chaste we must shun idleness, bad companions, the reading of bad books and papers, intemperance, the sight of indecent statues or pictures, licentious theatres, dangerous conversations, and all other occasions of sin.

questions.question: What does the Seventh Commandment, Thou shalt not steal, forbid?
questions.answer: The Seventh Commandment, Thou shalt not steal, forbids all unjust taking and all unjust keeping of what belongs to another, and also every other way of wronging our neighbour in his property.

questions.question: What is meant by stealing?
questions.answer: It means taking another's goods unjustly and against the owner's will, that is to say, when he has every reason and right to be unwilling to be deprived of them.

questions.question: Why is it forbidden to steal?
questions.answer: Because a sin is committed against justice and an injury is done to another by taking or keeping against his right and will that which belongs to him.

questions.question: What is meant by another's goods?
questions.answer: Everything that belongs to him everything of which he has the ownership, or the use, or the custody.

questions.question: In how many ways can another's goods be unjustly taken?
questions.answer: In two ways: by theft and by robbery.

questions.question: How is theft committed?
questions.answer: Theft is committed by taking another's goods secretly.

questions.question: How is robbery committed?
questions.answer: Robbery is committed by taking another's goods openly and with violence.

questions.question: In what cases may another's goods be taken without sin?
questions.answer: When the owner consents or even when he unjustly refuses. Thus, one in extreme necessity may take another's goods without sin, provided that he takes only so much as is absolutely necessary to relieve pressing and extreme need.

questions.question: Is it only by theft and robbery that another can be injured in his property?
questions.answer: He can also be injured by fraud, usury, and any other act of injustice directed against his goods.

questions.question: How is fraud committed?
questions.answer: Fraud is committed in trade by deceiving another by false weight, measure and money or by bad goods; by falsifying writings and documents; in short, by deceit in buying and selling or in contracts in general, as well as by refusing to pay what is just and agreed upon.

questions.question: How is usury committed?
questions.answer: Usury is committed by exacting, without just title, an unlawful interest for money lent, thus taking an unfair advantage of another's need or ignorance.

questions.question: What other sorts of injustice may be committed with regard to another's goods?
questions.answer: By unjustly causing him to lose what he has; by injuring him in his possessions; by not working as in duty bound; by maliciously refusing to pay debts or wages due; by wounding or killing his stock; by damaging property held in custody; by preventing another from making just gains; by aiding thieves; and by receiving, concealing or buying stolen goods.

questions.question: Is it a grave sin to steal?
questions.answer: It is a grave sin against justice when the matter is grave; for it is most important for the good of individuals, of families, and of society that each one's right to his property should be respected.

questions.question: When is stolen matter grave?
questions.answer: When that which is taken is considerable, as also when serious loss is inflicted on another by taking that which in itself is of little value.

questions.question: What does the Seventh Commandment command?
questions.answer: The Seventh Commandment commands us to respect the property of others, to give the labourer fair wages, and to observe justice in all that concerns what belongs to others.

questions.question: Is it enough for one who has sinned against the Seventh Commandment to confess his sin?
questions.answer: It is not enough for one who has sinned against the Seventh Commandment to confess his sin; he must also do his best to restore what belongs to others, and to repair the loss he has caused.

questions.question: What is meant by repairing the losses caused?
questions.answer: Repairing the losses caused means the compensation which must be made to another for the goods or profits lost owing to the theft or other acts of injustice committed to his detriment.

questions.question: To whom must stolen property be restored?
questions.answer: To him from whom it has been stolen; to his heirs, if he is dead; or if this is really impossible the value of it should be devoted to the poor or to some charity.

questions.question: What should one do who finds something of great value?
questions.answer: He should diligently seek the owner and faithfully restore it to him.

questions.question: What does the Eighth Commandment, Thou shalt not bear false witness, forbid?
questions.answer: The Eighth Commandment, Thou shalt not bear false witness, forbids false testimony in a court of justice, and it also forbids backbiting, detraction, calumny, adulation, rash judgement and rash suspicion and every sort of lying.

questions.question: What is detraction or backbiting?
questions.answer: Detraction or backbiting is a sin which consists in making known another's sins and defects without sufficient reason.

questions.question: What is calumny?
questions.answer: Calumny is a sin which consists in maliciously attributing to another faults and defects which he did not possess.

questions.question: What is adulation?
questions.answer: Adulation is a sin which consists in deceiving another by falsely praising him or others for the purpose of profiting thereby.

questions.question: What is rash judgement or rash suspicion?
questions.answer: Rash judgement or rash suspicion is a sin which consists in judging or suspecting evil of others without sufficient foundation.

questions.question: What is a lie?
questions.answer: A lie is a sin which consists in asserting as true or false by word or act that which one does not believe to be really the case.

questions.question: How many kinds of lies are there?
questions.answer: There are three kinds: The jocose lie, the officious lie, and the malicious lie.

questions.question: What is a jocose lie?
questions.answer: A jocose lie is that which is told in jest and without injury to anyone.

questions.question: What is an officious lie?
questions.answer: An officious lie is a false statement to benefit oneself or another without injuring anyone else.

questions.question: What is a malicious lie?
questions.answer: A malicious lie is a false statement made to the injury of another.

questions.question: Is it ever lawful to tell a lie?
questions.answer: It is never lawful to tell a lie, neither in joke, nor for one's own benefit, nor for the benefit of another, because a lie is always bad in itself.

questions.question: What kind of sin is a lie?
questions.answer: A lie when jocose or officious is a venial sin; but when malicious it is a mortal sin if the harm done is grave.

questions.question: Is it always necessary to say all one's mind?
questions.answer: It is not always necessary, especially when he who questions you has no right to know what he demands.

questions.question: Is it enough for him who has sinned against the Eighth Commandment to confess the sin?
questions.answer: It is not enough for him who has sinned against the Eighth Commandment to confess the sin; he is also obliged to retract whatever he said when calumniating another, and to repair as far as he can the harm he has done.

questions.question: What does the Eighth Commandment command us to do?
questions.answer: The Eighth Commandment commands us to speak the truth at the proper time and place, and, as far as we can, to put a good interpretation upon the actions of our neighbour.

questions.question: What does the Tenth Commandment, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's goods, forbid?
questions.answer: The Tenth Commandment, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's goods, forbids the wish to deprive another of his goods and the wish to acquire goods by unjust means.

questions.question: Why does God forbid even the desire of another's goods?
questions.answer: God forbids the unregulated desire of another's goods, because He wishes us to be just even in thought and will, and to hold ourselves completely aloof from unjust acts.

questions.question: What does the Tenth Commandment command?
questions.answer: The Tenth Commandment commands us to be satisfied with the state in which God has placed us, and to bear poverty patiently should God have placed us in that condition.

questions.question: How can a Christian be content in a state of poverty?
questions.answer: A Christian can be content in a state of poverty by reflecting that our greatest good is a pure and peaceful conscience; that our true home is heaven; and that Jesus Christ made Himself poor for love of us and has promised a special reward to those who bear poverty patiently.

questions.question: Besides the Commandments of God what else must we observe?
questions.answer: Besides the Commandments of God we must also observe the Precepts of the Church.

questions.question: Are we obliged to obey the Church?
questions.answer: Undoubtedly we are obliged to obey the Church, because Jesus Christ Himself commands us to do so, and because the Precepts of the Church help us to observe the Commandments of God.

questions.question: When does the obligation to observe the Precepts of the Church begin to bind?
questions.answer: As arule the obligation to observe the Precepts of the Church begins to bind us as soon as we come to the age of reason.

questions.question: Is it a sin to transgress a Precept of the Church?
questions.answer: Knowingly to transgress a Precept of the Church in grave matter is a mortal sin.

questions.question: Who can dispense from a Precept of the Church?
questions.answer: Only the Pope, or one who has received from him the power to do so, can dispense from a Precept of the Church. **Name the Precepts of the Church.** The Precepts of the Church are: 1. To hear Mass on all Sundays and on Holydays of obligation. 2. To fast during Lent, on Ember Days and appointed Vigils, and not to eat meat on forbidden days. 3. To confess our sins at least once a year, and to receive Holy Communion at Easter each one in his own parish. 4. To contribute to the support of the Church, according to local custom. 5. Not to solemnise matriage at forbidden times, that is, from the first Sunday in Advent until the Epiphany, and from the first day of Lent until Low Sunday. #### The First Precept of the Church

questions.question: What does the First Precept of the Church: To hear Mass on all Sundays and on Holydays of obligation, order us to do?
questions.answer: The First Precept of the Church: To hear Mass on all Sundays and on Holydays of obligations, orders us to assist devoutly at Mass on all Sundays and on Holydays of obligation.

questions.question: At which Mass does the Church desire us to assist on Sundays and on Holydays of obligation?
questions.answer: The Mass at which the Church desires us to assist, if possible, on Sundays and Holydays of obligation is the Parochial Mass.

questions.question: Why does the Church recommend the faithful to assist at the Parochial Mass?
questions.answer: The Church recommends the faithful to assist at the Parochial Mass: (1) In order that all the parishioners of the same parish may unite in prayer together with their Pastor, who is their head; (2) In order that the parishioners may participate more abundantly in the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass, which is applied principally for them; (3) In order that they may hear the truths of the Gospel, which Pastors are bound to explain during Mass; (4) In order that they may learn the regulations and notices which are published at that Mass.

questions.question: What is meant by the Lord's Day?
questions.answer: The Lord's Day means the day of the Lord, that is, the day specially consecrated to divine service.

questions.question: Why in the First Precept of the Church is special mention made of the Lord's day?
questions.answer: In the First Precept of the Church special mention is made of the Lord's Day, because it is the principal Christian festival, as the Sabbath was the principal Jewish festival, and because it was instituted by God Himself.

questions.question: What other festivals have been instituted by the Church?
questions.answer: The Church has instituted Feasts of our Lord, of the Blessed Virgin, of the Angels and of the Saints.

questions.question: Why did the Church institute other Festivals of our Lord?
questions.answer: The Church instituted other Festivals of our Lord in memory of His divine Mysteries.

questions.question: And why have Festivals of the Blessed Virgin and of the Saints been instituted?
questions.answer: Festivals of the Blessed Virgin and of the Saints have been instituted: (1) In memory of the graces which God has given them, and to thank His divine goodness; (2) In order that we may honour them, imitate their example, and be aided by their prayers. [The universal law of the Church reckons ten Holydays of obligation: the feasts of Christmas, the Circumcision, the Epiphany, the Ascension, Corpus Christi, the Immaculate Conception, the Assumption, Saint Joseph, Saints Peter and Paul, and All Saints. In many countries, by local concessions, they are reduced.] #### The Second Precept of the Church

questions.question: What is commanded by the Second Precept of the Church in the words, To fast on the days prescribed?
questions.answer: By the words, To fast on the days prescribed, the Second Precept of the Church commands us to observe the fast: (1) During Lent; (2) On certain days of Advent, where this is prescribed; (3) On Ember Days; (4) And on certain Vigils.

questions.question: In what does fasting consist?
questions.answer: Fasting consists in taking but one meal a day and in abstaining from prohibited kinds of food.

questions.question: On fast days may a collation be taken in the evening?
questions.answer: Through the concession of the Church, a collation may be taken in the evening on fast days.

questions.question: What is the good of fasting?
questions.answer: Fasting serves to dispose us better to prayer; to do penance for past sins; and to preserve us from sinning again.

questions.question: Who are bound to fast?
questions.answer: Every Christian over twenty-one years of age who is not dispensed, or excused for some good reason, is bound to fast.

questions.question: Are those who are not bound to fast, exempt from all mortification?
questions.answer: Those who are not bound by the obligation of fasting are not exempt from all mortification, because all are bound to do penance.

questions.question: For what purpose has Lent been instituted?
questions.answer: Lent has been instituted to imitate in some way the rigorous fast of forty days undergone by Jesus Christ in the desert, and to prepare us by penitential exercises to celebrate the feast of Easter devoutly.

questions.question: Why has the Advent fast been instituted?
questions.answer: The Advent fast has been instituted to prepare us to celebrate devoutly the Feast of our Lord's Nativity.

questions.question: Why has the fast of Ember Days been instituted?
questions.answer: The fast of Ember Days has been instituted: (1) To consecrate each of the Four Seasons of the year by some days' penance; (2) To beg of God the preservation of the fruits of the earth; (3) To thank Him for those already given us; (4) And to beseech Him to give good priests to His Church, the usual days for ordaining priests being the Ember Saturdays.

questions.question: Why has fasting on Vigils been instituted?
questions.answer: Fasting on Vigils has been instituted to prepare us to celebrate the principal Feasts devoutly.

questions.question: What is forbidden on Fridays, and also on Saturdays where not dispensed?
questions.answer: On Fridays, and also on Saturdays where not dispensed, it is forbidden to eat meat, except in case of necessity.

questions.question: Why does the Church wish us to abstain from eating meat on these days?
questions.answer: In order that we may do penance each week, and especially on Friday, in honour of the Passion, and on Saturdays in memory of the burial of Jesus Christ, and in honour of the Blessed Virgin. [From the Code of Canon Law of 1917, with the modifications Approved in 1949, (complete) abstinence only is to be observed on all the Fridays throughout the year. Fast and (complete) abstinence is to be observed on Ash Wednesday, the Fridays of Lent, Ember Fridays, the Vigils of the Assumption and Christmas, and Holy Saturday. Fast only (and partial abstinence) is to be observed on: all weekdays of Lent, Ember Wednesdays and Saturdays, and the Vigils of Pentecost and All Saints. On the days of fast, only one full meal is allowed. Two other meatless snacks, sufficient to maintain strength may be taken according to each one's needs, but together they should not equal another full meal. Meat may be taken at the principal meal on a day of fast except on the days of complete abstinence. Eating between meals is forbidden, but liquids including milk and fruit juices are allowed. On holydays of obligation, except in Lent, there is neither fast nor abstinence. The laws of abstinence binds all who have completed their seventh year of age; the law of fasting binds all persons from the completion of their twenty first year until the beginning of their sixtieth. (The completion of the seventh year means the day after the seventh birthday). According to the 1983 Code of Canon Law, 'All Fridays through the year and the time of Lent are penitential days and times throughout the universal Church. Abstinence from eating meat. . . is to be observed on Fridays throughout the year unless they are solemnities; abstinence and fast are to be observed on Ash Wednesday and [Good] Friday. All adults who have completed their fourteenth year are bound by the law of abstinence; all adults [from age 18] are bound by the law of fast up to the beginning of their sixtieth year.' The Episcopal Conference can modify these general rules. In the United States, 'Catholics are obliged to abstain from the eating of meat on Ash Wednesday and all Fridays during the season of Lent. They are also obliged to fast on Ash Wednesday and on Good Friday. Self-imposed observances of fasting on all weekdays of Lent is strongly recommended. Abstinence from flesh meat on all Fridays of the year is especially recommended to individuals and to the Catholic community as a whole.' In Australia, 'Abstinence from meat, and fasting, are to be observed on Ash Wednesday and Good Friday. On all other Fridays of the year the law of the common practice of penance is fulfilled by performing any of the following: (a) prayer, as for example Mass attendance, family prayer, .. . (b) self-denial, e.g. not eating meat, not eating sweets or dessert, . . (c) helping others, e.g. special attention to someone who is poor, sick, elderly, .. .' Since a clarity and precision in a law helps for its fulfilment, the faithful are strongly recommended to follow the traditional rules, though only the recent regulations oblige under pain of mortal sin.] #### The Third Precept of the Church

questions.question: What does the Church command us in the words of the Third Precept: To go to Confession at least once a year?
questions.answer: By the words of the Third Precept: To go to Confession a least once a year, the Church obliges all Christians, who have come to the use of reason, to approach the sacrament of Penance at least once a year.

questions.question: What is the best time to satisfy the precept of annual Confession?
questions.answer: The best time to satisfy the precept of annual Confession is Lent, in accordance with the usage introduced and approved by the whole Church.

questions.question: Why does the Church say that we are to confess at least once a year?
questions.answer: The Church uses the words at least to let us see her desire that we should approach the sacraments more frequently.

questions.question: Is it useful, then, to go often to Confession?
questions.answer: It is most useful to go often to Confession, especially as it is difficult for one who goes only rarely to make a good Confession and to avoid mortal sin.

questions.question: What does the Church command us to do by the other words of the Third Precept: To receive Holy Communion at Easter, each one in his own parish?
questions.answer: By the words of the Third Precept: To receive Holy Communion at Easter, each one in his own parish, the Church obliges all Christians who have come to the age of discretion to receive the Blessed Eucharist every year at Paschal time in their own parish.

questions.question: Are we bound to go to Holy Communion at other times besides Easter?
questions.answer: We are also bound to go to Holy Communion when in danger of death.

questions.question: Why is it said that we are to receive Holy Communion at least at Easter?
questions.answer: Because the Church earnestly desires us to approach Holy Communion which is the divine food of our souls, not only at Easter, but as often as we possibly can.

questions.question: Is this Precept fulfilled by a sacrilegious Confession or a sacrilegious Communion?
questions.answer: This Precept of the Church is not fulfilled by sacrilegious Confession and Communion, because the intention of the Church is that we receive those Sacraments for the end on account of which they were instituted, that is, for our sanctification. #### The Fourth Precept of the Church

questions.question: How are we to observe the Fourth Precept: To contribute to due support of the Church?
questions.answer: The Fourth Precept is satisfied by paying the dues or making the offerings which have been established in recognition of God's supreme dominion over all things and as a means of providing for the becoming support of His ministers.

questions.question: How are these dues and offerings to be paid?
questions.answer: They are to be paid in the way and manner customary in the place in which we live. #### The Fifth Precept of the Church

questions.question: What does the Church forbid in the Fifth Precept: Not to solemnise marriage at forbidden times?
questions.answer: In the Fifth Precept the Church does not forbid the celebration of the sacrament of marriage; but only the nuptial solemnities, from the first Sunday of Advent until the Epiphany, and from the first day of Lent until Low Sunday.

questions.question: What are the nuptial solemnities which are forbidden?
questions.answer: The nuptial solemnities forbidden by this Precept are the celebration of the nuptial Mass, the nuptial benediction, and marriage festivities on a large scale.

questions.question: Why are marriage festivities on a large scale out of place in Advent and Lent?
questions.answer: Pompous displays are out of place in Advent and Lent because these seasons are specially consecrated to penance and prayer.

questions.question: What is a supernatural virtue?
questions.answer: A supernatural virtue is a quality infused by God into the soul by which the latter acquires inclination, facility, and promptness to know good and do it towards eternal life.

questions.question: How many principal supernatural virtues are there?
questions.answer: The principal supernatural virtues are seven: three theological, and four cardinal virtues.

questions.question: What are the theological virtues?
questions.answer: The theological virtues are: Faith, Hope and Charity.

questions.question: Why are Faith, Hope and Charity called theological virtues?
questions.answer: Faith, Hope and Charity are called theological virtues, because they have God as their immediate and principal object, and are infused by Him.

questions.question: How can the theological virtues have God for their immediate object?
questions.answer: The theological virtues have God for their immediate object, in this way that by Faith we believe in God, and believe all He has revealed; by Hope, we hope to possess God; and by Charity, we love God and in Him we love ourselves and our neighbour.

questions.question: When does God infuse the theological virtues into the soul?
